Fig. 28 Photo-/electrocatalytic approaches to CO2 conversion on Cu2O-based catalysts Zixuan Zhao a Hongtao Wang a ⁎ Qi Yu b Soumendra Roy b Xiaohu Yu b ⁎ a College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, People’s Republic of China College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan 030024 People’s Republic of China College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, People’s Republic of China b Shaanxi Key laboratory of Catalysis and School of Chemical of Chemical & Environment Sciences, Shaanxi University of Technology, Hanzhong 723000, People’s Republic of China Shaanxi Key laboratory of Catalysis and School of Chemical of Chemical & Environment Sciences, Shaanxi University of Technology Hanzhong 723000 People’s Republic of China Shaanxi Key laboratory of Catalysis and School of Chemical of Chemical & Environment Sciences, Shaanxi University of Technology, Hanzhong 723000, People’s Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Carbon dioxide (CO2) reduction reaction (CO2RR) with renewable energy represents a promising way for effective utilization of the major anthropogenic greenhouse gas. Cuprous oxide (Cu2O)-based catalysts have attracted great attention in recent years due to abundant reserves, lower price, environmental friendliness, and higher activity of CO2RR. Moreover, Cu+ site in Cu2O plays an important role in improving the C2+ product selectivity. This paper reviews recent advances of photo- and electrocatalytic CO2RR on Cu2O-based catalysts in both experimental and computational studies. Firstly, the basic principle of photo- and electrocatalytic CO2RR on Cu2O-based catalysts is briefly reviewed. Secondly, various strategies have been adopted to improve CO2RR catalytic performance of Cu2O-based catalysts, mainly including morphology control, heterojunction engineering, metal deposition, and defective engineering. Finally, potential strategies to further promote CO2RR have also been suggested: including single atom catalyst, double atom catalyst, single cluster catalyst, and frustrated Lewis pairs, etc. We hope that the present comprehensive overview paves the way for future development of CO2RR on Cu2O-based catalysts. Graphical Abstract A comprehensive review of the development status of Cu2O-based catalysts in photo-/electrocatalytic CO2RR is given, with emphasis on the nature of Cu2O as well as modification strategies. ga1 Keywords Cu2O-Based Catalysts CO2 reduction reaction Catalyst modification C2+ product Selectivity Data Availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction With the excessive burning of fossil fuels, including coal and oil, in the past two centuries, carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions have increased significantly. As a major greenhouse gas, its massive emissions have exacerbated the Earth's natural greenhouse phenomenon, triggering a series of problems such as global warming and sea level rise [1]. In order to decrease the serious eco-crisis and energy security issues, it is urgent to reduce the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere [2]. Based on this, many countries have proposed the dual carbon goals of "carbon peaking" and "carbon neutrality" [3,4]. The commonly used technologies to mitigate CO2 emissions are carbon capture, utilization and storage (CCUS) [5]. Among them, catalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) for the production of high-value chemicals has attracted great attention. However, the CO2 molecule exhibits a linear symmetric structure with the elemental carbon in the highest oxidation state. It has a short C-O bond length of 0.116 nm and has the property of a partial triple bond. It also has a high bond energy (750 kJ/mol), and a huge energy input is required to break the C-O double bond. Overall, the CO2 molecule is chemically stable, with some thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertia. So, the activation and conversion of the CO2 molecule is really difficult. In addition, the complex reaction process of CO2RR including multi-step electron transfer, hydrogenation and C-C bond coupling makes the conversion and utilization of CO2 into a high energy consumption and low efficiency dilemma [6]. Light, electricity, and heat can provide essential energy inputs in photocatalysis, electrocatalysis, and thermocatalysis of CO2RR, breaking bonds in reactant molecules (CO2, H2 and H2O) and promoting the formation of new bonds [7]. Among them, thermocatalysis of CO2RR can generate a large number of products as well as liquid fuels. But it requires high temperature and pressure operating conditions and consumes a certain amount of fossil energy [8]. In contrast to thermocatalytic processes, photo-/electrocatalysis can use solar and electrical energy to drive the reduction conversion of CO2 to C1 or C2+. One advantage of photo-/electrocatalysis is mild reaction condition, which can avoid the high temperature and pressure operating condition of direct CO2 hydrogenation reactions in industry. Another advantage is that it is green, which can directly or indirectly use renewable energy as an energy donor [9,10]. So, photo- and electrocatalysis of CO2RR are essential for achieving the sustainable use of new energy and the very promising strategies for achieving carbon neutrality. In the photo-/electrocatalytic process, complex reactions can be facilitated to reduce the reaction potential by adding catalysts. First, photocatalysts and electrocatalysts can facilitate the electron transfer process during the reaction, providing the energy required to activate CO2 molecules through light energy or electricity. Electrocatalysts can reduce the activation overpotential required for reactions. Second, the photocatalysts and electrocatalysts provides active sites that can optimize the reaction pathway. By providing new reaction pathways, the reaction activation barrier can be reduced. That is to say, the catalyst can adsorb CO2 molecules and generate new intermediates. Active sites affect the adsorption behaviour of reaction intermediates, reduce their interaction forces, and create a more favourable reaction environment. Thus, the reaction has a lower activation barrier. A suitable catalyst is the key for efficient photo- and electrocatalysis of CO2RR. Among many CO2 reduction catalysts, Cu2O, as a common semiconductor material, has received much attention from researchers because of its abundant reserves, environmental friendliness, and outstanding performance. The development of Cu2O-based catalysts in the photo-/electrocatalytic CO2RR is shown in Fig. 1. In photocatalytic CO2RR, the advantages of Cu2O catalyst are that Cu2O has the suitable band gap (2.2 eV) which is benefit to the visible light response, and it has a more negative conduction band potential, which is lower than the CO2RR potential and can theoretically catalyze the reduction of CO2 [11,12]; the disadvantages of Cu2O catalyst are the high photo-generated electron-hole complex rate and severe photo-corrosion [13]. In electrocatalytic CO2 reduction, the excellent performance of copper-based catalysts for the reduction of CO2 to C2+ products has gained the attention of researchers [14]. Among them, Cu2O catalysts have attracted much attention and have been extensively studied due to better Faraday efficiency (FE) of C2 products (C2H4, C2H5OH) [15–17]. But, in comparison, liquid products such as n-propanol have a lower FE [18]. Moreover, the variable valence state of Cu2O during the electrochemical process affects the adsorption behaviour of the intermediate products, which is conducive to lowering the reaction potential barrier [19,20]. However, the products of CO2RR are diverse, such as CO, CH4, CH3OH, C2H4, C2H5OH. Due to the similar reaction potentials [21], mixed products are sometimes generated. Moreover, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) acts as a competitive side reaction of the water-based CO2 reduction system, resulting in additional energy consumption and reaction inefficiency, also for Cu2O. In summary, it was shown that the ratio of copper valence states in the catalyst affect the progress of CO2RR and HER. Deng et al. [22] investigated the role of different Cu valence fractions in the CO2RR process and showed that the surface ratio of Cu fractions was linearly related to the selectivity of the corresponding products. Cu0 was the active site of CH4, while Cu2O was the active site of CO, and the stronger adsorption and activation of CO by Cu0 promoted its further conversion. Yang et al. [23] suggested that during CO2RR, Cu2+ was reduced to generate Cu0 and Cu+, Cu0 activates CO2 and promotes electron transfer, while Cu+ enhances *CO adsorption and promotes C-C coupling. The independent Cu0 site mainly generates CH4 and the mixed site favours C2H4. Ren et al. [24] showed that Cu2O with an appropriate ratio of coordinately unsaturated copper atoms after reduction optimizes the adsorption of the intermediate CHxO thereby facilitating the generation of C2H4 and C2H5OH. But an excess of coordinated unsaturated atoms will, in turn, promote HER as its binding to H atoms becomes stronger. That is, the variable valence states of Cu2O provide an opportunity for HER to occur. We need to optimize its oxidation state ratios so that the reaction proceeds in the direction we expect. In addition, in previous studies, the interactions of small molecules with Cu2O and CuO have been extensively studied [25–32]. Overall, Cu2O shows great potential in photo-/electrocatalytic CO2RR. Although its catalytic activity is limited, it is still considered as an ideal material for photo-/electrocatalysis. Besides, there are also a few studies on the application of Cu2O in the fields of photo-electric catalysis [33–36] and photo-thermal catalysis [37]. The catalytic performance of Cu2O can be further improved by modifying it to meet the practical application requirements, such as carefully designing the morphology and composition of the catalyst. A number of strategies have been reported for improving the catalytic performance of Cu2O. For example, the selection of catalyst morphology and crystal facet directly determines the light absorption capacity and catalytic sites of the catalyst [19,38–40]; the construction of heterojunction or carbon matrix composites can effectively solve the shortcomings of photo-generated electron-hole complexation and improve charge transfer efficiency [41–43]; the introduction of another metal, by creating synergy with the semiconductor, affects the adsorption behaviour of the intermediate and improves the reaction selectivity [44,45]; and defective constructions allow flexible modulation of the local electronic structure of the catalyst and are critical to the reaction as active sites [46–49]. In summary, numerous factors have been shown to have a significant impact on CO2RR, such as copper valence states, unsaturated coordination sites, grain boundaries, vacancy defects, and doping atoms [50]. All of them can act as important active sites to influence the charge carrier transport efficiency and the adsorption behaviour of intermediates on the catalyst. Or some of them can interact synergistically with the catalyst, thus improving the stability and activity of the catalyst. However, no conclusions have been reached regarding the active phase/active substance in the copper oxide-mediated CO2RR. There are many opinions on the reasons for the increased catalytic activity and selectivity of the reaction, and the following are some of the current possible explanations: (1) Increase in electrochemically active surface area (ECSA). Wang et al. [51] demonstrated that increasing the roughness factor of copper electrode can reduce CO to generate multicarbon oxygenated oxides at low overpotential. This here, the increase in ECSA not only increased the reaction yield but also modulated the reaction selectivity. (2) Stronger intermediates binding sites. Lee et al. [15] showed that the intermediate CO has stronger binding energy on the Cu2O surface compared to pure metallic copper. And the high CO coverage favours the C-C coupling. (3) Higher density of grain boundaries. The study confirms the importance of grain boundaries in improving catalytic performance, with the potential to produce surfaces of long-lasting catalytic activity [52,53]. We can design grain boundaries to improve the selectivity of the C2 product by changing the reduction method of the oxide, for example. (4) Inhibition of CO protonation. When Yano et al. [16] investigated CO2 reduction on a copper electrode, they found that the Cu2O produced on the copper electrode favoured the selective generation of C2H4. The reason for this is that the presence of Cu2O hinders the protonation process of CO, thereby facilitating the C-C coupling reaction. (5) The synergistic effect of Cu0-Cu+. The synergistic effect of Cu0-Cu+ gives high efficiency to the reaction, improves the activation of CO2 molecules and *CO dimerization, and facilitates the generation of C2H4 [20,54,55]. Furthermore, Lin et al. [17] showed that the Cu0-Cu+ mixed valence region favours the formation of surface OH species. Catalysts with Cu0-Cu+ first provided asymmetric OCCO adsorption sites and subsequently promoted C2H5OH selectivity through the carboxylate stabilization effect of the OH group. Based on the above research, it is necessary to summarize a systematic review covering various types of strategies that can effectively improve the catalytic performance of Cu2O, especially for the environmentally friendly and easy-to-operate photo-/electrocatalytic CO2RR. A number of detailed reviews based on copper-based catalysts already exist. For example, Baran et al. [56] mainly reviewed the research progress of copper-based semiconductors as photocathodes in the areas of water decomposition and CO2 reduction, etc. Zhang et al. [57] reviewed the modification strategies of Cu2O-based photocatalysts and their applications, and discussed in detail the charge transfer pathways in photocatalysis. And Meng et al. [58] reviewed some modification strategies of copper-based catalysts for electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 in recent years. In addition, for theoretical studies, Zhang et al. [59] summarized the recent progress in simulating CO2RR and briefly introduced the application of machine learning (ML) in CO2RR. And the main purpose of this review is to gain insight into the current status of research on Cu2O-based catalysts in photo-/electrocatalytic CO2RR. We would like to study systematically on the application of modification strategies for Cu2O-based catalysts in CO2RR. Compared with the existing review studies on Cu-based catalysts, we focus on the application of Cu2O in photo-/electrocatalytic CO2RR. The article ranges from the existing common modification strategies used for Cu2O to the development of new efficient catalysts in the future, which is important for the design of efficient Cu2O-based CO2 photo-/electrocatalysts. Firstly, this paper analyzes the feasibility of Cu2O photo-/electrocatalytic CO2 reduction and briefly introduces the basic principles of photo-/electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. Secondly, the article provides a comprehensive review of different modification strategies used on Cu2O catalysts in recent years, in terms of both photocatalysis and electrocatalysis. For photocatalysts, the catalytic performance is mainly improved by morphology modulation, construction heterojunction or carbon-based composites, metal deposition and elemental doping. While for electrocatalysts, the main focus is on morphology modulation, metal deposition and defect engineering strategies. This is important for an in-depth understanding of the mechanisms influencing the activity, selectivity, and stability of the reaction. The main determinants of catalytic performance lie in the active site, defects, grain boundaries, and synergistic interactions among the components, etc. Finally, the article suggests the future development trend of Cu2O catalysts. We analyzed the development potential of atomically dispersed catalysts (ADCs), dual doping catalysts, frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs) catalysts and tandem catalysts. These new and efficient catalysts have shown great advantages but have not been widely studied and applied to Cu2O. It also provides an outlook on the application of ML in CO2RR. We hope that this work will provide a reference for the design of Cu2O-based catalysts in industry and be a guide for the future direction of catalyst development. 2 Fundamentals of CO2 reduction In this section, the basic principles of photo-, electro-, and thermocatalytic CO2RR are briefly introduced. The differences in energy donors, reaction conditions and environments lead to differences in the mechanisms of photo-, electro-, and thermocatalytic CO2 reduction. Understanding the reaction principles of CO2 reduction is an important guide for the design of catalysts. 2.1 Photocatalytic CO2 reduction The photocatalytic CO2RR can be divided into five steps [60]: (1) adsorption of CO2; (2) semiconductor light absorption; (3) separation and transfer of photo-generated electron-hole; (4) occurrence of redox reaction; (5) desorption of products. As shown in Fig. 3(a), light irradiation produces electrons and holes in the semiconductor catalyst, which subsequently migrate to the catalyst surface for the reaction. Among them, the photo-generated electrons are used for CO2 reduction and the holes are used for water oxidation. The final reaction product is desorbed on the catalyst surface and the reaction is completed. The products of photocatalytic CO2RR are mainly CO, HCOOH, CH4 and CH3OH (Table S1). The reaction conditions are mild, only solar energy is consumed during the whole reaction process, and no additional energy input is required. In photocatalysis, the photo-responsiveness of the semiconductor and the separation and transport efficiency of the photo-generated carriers have a great impact on the reaction efficiency. Then the adsorption capacity of the catalyst surface on the key intermediates affects the formation and release of products, and a suitable adsorption capacity facilitates the reaction. Therefore, photocatalysts for CO2 reduction need to have a suitable band gap, a low photo-generated electron-hole complexation rate, and high catalytic activity. 2.2 Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction The electrocatalytic CO2RR can be divided into the following four steps [61]: (1) CO2 chemisorption; (2) electron and proton transport; (3) occurrence of redox reaction; (4) desorption of products. A typical electrocatalytic reactor (proton exchange membrane reactor) is shown in Fig. 3(b). For CO2RR, the reduction of CO2 occurs at the cathode, while the oxidation of water is generally carried out at the anode, and the electrolyte should have good CO2 solubility. CO2 is first adsorbed on the catalyst surface and subsequently interacts with electrons/protons to form the corresponding products. And finally, the products are desorbed from the catalyst surface into the electrolyte. The products of electrocatalytic CO2 RR mainly include C1 products such as CO, CH4 and CH3OH, and C2 products such as C2H5OH and C2H4 (Table S1), the reaction process is relatively mild and has a wide range of products. Since electrocatalytic CO2 reduction usually occurs in aqueous solutions, it is often accompanied by competing HER, resulting in a low FE of the target product. 2.3 Thermocatalytic CO2 reduction Thermocatalytic CO2RR is the reduction decomposition of CO2 by using high temperature and catalyst, which usually refers to CO2 hydrogenation reaction and CH4 reforming reaction. As shown in Table S1, in addition to the hydrogenation of CO2 to hydrocarbons, thermal catalysis also includes the generation of synthesis gas via CH4 reforming reaction, i.e. CO/H2, which is an important feedstock for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. For CH4 reforming reactions, the reactions usually occur at high temperatures (600 ∼ 1000 °C) due to the high stability of CO2 and CH4, and the process has a serious drawback - catalyst deactivation caused by carbon deposition; for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, the reaction temperature is relatively mild (250 ∼ 400 °C) and the hydrogenation activation of CO2 is thermodynamically favourable, but the high stability of CO2 and the high reaction potential of C-C coupling lead to relative difficulties in generating C2 products compared to C1 [21]. Therefore, in general, unlike high-temperature CO2 hydrogenation in thermal catalysis, photo- and electrocatalysis are essentially the same. Except for the different external energy utilized, they both involve the activated adsorption of CO2 on the catalyst surface, followed by a redox reaction that converts CO2 into a useful chemical. They also have some common thermodynamic basis, differing in that electrocatalysis has a relatively more complex C2 generation process. In addition, the catalytic reduction of CO2 is essentially a multi-electron transfer process, and the reaction is more complex with more pathways for product generation. From Table S1, we can see that the CO2 molecule has a high activation potential (-1.9 V vs NHE pH=7, or -1.49 V vs RHE) and the activation of CO2 is relatively more difficult compared to the subsequent generation of some reaction intermediates. In addition, since the electrocatalytic CO2RR usually occurs in aqueous solution and the close onset potentials, the HER is a common competitive side reaction in the CO2RR process. In a word, the high overpotential and the similar reaction potential of some products give the CO2RR a low conversion efficiency and selectivity. In the face of these problems, these three technologies are still progressing and evolving, and we cannot predict which one will be dominant in the future. Our current main task is to explore and develop suitable catalysts to improve the stability, mass transfer efficiency and other properties, which will be important for the improvement of reaction activity and selectivity. 3 Research status of Cu2O photocatalytic CO2 reduction Photocatalytic CO2 reduction can directly use solar energy to achieve the reduction of CO2, simulating the photosynthesis of plants in nature. It is carried out at room temperature and pressure with mild reaction conditions, which is an effective method to alleviate current problems such as energy issues and global warming [60]. Photocatalysis technology has attracted widespread attention for its green and renewable solar energy. It has potential application value and a good development prospect. However, photocatalytic CO2 reduction also faces many problems, such as the high activation potential of CO2 molecules, complex multi-electron reaction process, unfavourable thermodynamics and low selectivity of value-added products [62]. The search for catalysts with abundant reserves, excellent performance and high plasticity is the key to solving the above problems, which is beneficial for promoting the industrial application of photocatalytic CO2 reduction. 3.1 Advantages and shortcomings of Cu2O for photocatalytic CO2RR 3.1.1 Advantages As a common p-type semiconductor, Cu2O, which is abundant and environmentally friendly, has a suitable band gap (2-2.2 eV [11]) and a maximum absorption wavelength of about 560 nm, possessing a wide visible response range. And its theoretical photoelectric conversion efficiency is up to 20%, which can effectively utilize solar energy [63]. Second, Cu2O has a favourable energy band structure and possesses a more negative conduction band potential [12]. As shown in Fig. 4, the Cu2O conduction potential (-1.15 V vs. SHE) is lower than the catalytic reduction reaction potential of CO2, which can theoretically reduce CO2 to a variety of hydrocarbons [12]. It shows an attractive prospect in the catalytic reduction of CO2. 3.1.2 Limitations The Cu2O photocatalytic CO2RR suffers from three main problems: (1) A high complexation rate between photo-generated electrons and holes. This higher complexation rate leads to a lower utilization of photo-generated electron-hole, which greatly limits the photocatalytic activity [57]. (2) Severe photo-corrosion, which leads to a catalyst with poor stability [13]. The redox potential of Cu2O is located between its band gaps (Fig. 4(b)) and undergoes autoluminescent oxidation/reduction, hindering the overall reaction performance. Studies on the photo-corrosion mechanism of semiconductors have shown that the above problems can be solved by improving the effective transport and utilization of photo-generated electrons and holes [64]. (3) Valence band potential that is not favourable for water oxidation [12]. Bifunctional catalysts are desirable. Unfortunately, the Cu2O valence band potential is lower than the water oxidation potential, and the reduction of CO2 and the oxidation of water cannot be achieved on the same catalyst (Fig. 4(b)). This requires the modulation of the Cu2O energy band structure. 3.2 Strategies for building efficient Cu2O-based photocatalysts 3.2.1 Morphology and crystal facet modulation The most common problem of the Cu2O photocatalytic CO2RR is that the photo-generated electron-hole is easy to compound or cannot be transferred and utilized in time, causing photo-corrosion. The transfer of photo-generated electrons from the interior of the catalyst to the surface is the key to the photocatalytic reaction. Modulation of catalyst morphology and crystal facet are common methods to enhance its light absorption and improve electron transport, which can effectively remedy the above problems. The morphological structure of the catalyst has an important influence on the photocatalytic efficiency. For example, nanostructured photocatalysts provide a larger effective area and reaction sites, which are favourable for CO2 capture and conversion [65]. Thin film catalysts with uniformly distributed structures can improve the utilization and stability of visible light. Compared to bulk materials, there are abundant grain boundaries on the surface of thin films, which can promote charge transport between interfaces and lead to local electric field changes, improving the activity and stability of the catalysts [66,67]. Moreover, in addition to promoting the efficient utilization of charge, grain boundaries with mixed Cu valence states will further improve the selectivity of C2 product. The main reason for this is that the synergistic effect of Cu0-Cu+ enhances the adsorption of intermediate *CO, and the active site Cu+ promotes the occurrence of C-C coupling [68,69]. Nano-sized dendritic porous structures, on the other hand, can increase the reaction area and improve light collection. And it helps to improve the efficiency of photo-generated electron-hole transport and the mass transfer efficiency of CO2. Cui et al. [39] investigated the application of 3D-porous Cu2O with dendritic structure in catalytic CO2. They confirmed that the rough dendritic porous structure significantly improved the photo-generated carrier concentration (2.5-fold increase) and photo-corrosion resistance on Cu2O with a significant increase in CO yield. Edge-truncated Cu2O catalysts containing polycrystalline facets have also received attention in recent years for CO2 reactions [66]. The difference in the work function of different crystal facets affects the electron energy band structure and charge separation. It is confirmed that the charge separation can be realized in the anisotropic surface of the crystal, thus effectively solving the problem of easy compounding of Cu2O photo-generated electron-hole. Recently, Chen et al. [67] investigated the effect of facet engineering combined with defect construction on the charge separation behaviour on Cu2O catalysts, as shown in Fig. 5(a). The built-in electric field between the crystal facets generated by facet engineering drives the accumulation of photo-generated electrons on the Cu2O (001) surface (Fig. 5(b)-(c)). The reason for this is that the (001) surface has a more significant P-type feature due to the higher Cu vacancy density. And the electric field becomes significant as the (111)/(001) ratio increases. On this basis, the researchers introduced the strategy of spatially controlled defect engineering (hydrogen-compensated Cu vacancy defects (H-VCu)). It can selectively extract holes to the (111) surface (Fig. 5(d)), while maintaining the accumulation of electrons on the (001) surface. And they showed that extreme (H-VCu) binding is not conducive to this process, leading to the disappearance of surface electrons and diffusion of holes (Fig. 5(e)). That is, anisotropic surface engineering and defect engineering simultaneously ensure the transfer of electrons between facets to catalytic surfaces and defect-induced hole transfer to spatially separated surfaces. In addition to copper vacancies, the formation of oxygen vacancies in metal oxides can modulate the reducibility of metal oxides. The catalytic performance is enhanced by affecting the light absorption reaction, the transport of photo-generated carriers, and the promotion of the reaction in three ways [70]. The strategy of morphology modulation combined with defect engineering provides a good direction for catalyst development. 3.2.2 Heterojunction engineering To improve the photocatalytic activity of Cu2O, one of the important ways is to promote charge separation efficiency. Constructing Cu2O-based heterojunctions can improve photocatalytic efficiency by improving the light absorption range and photo-generated electron-hole separation efficiency [42,71]. At the same time, newly formed Cu2O-based heterojunctions can avoid the occurrence of Cu2O photo-corrosion. In addition, both catalysts in the Cu2O-based heterojunction participate in the reaction as the main catalyst, exhibiting high stability and photocatalytic efficiency. Fig. 6(a)-(c) show the common heterojunctions, which are divided into three types according to the mid-layer method: conventional type-I, type-II and type-III photocatalysts [72]. It can be seen from the figure that one semiconductor energy band is located between another semiconductor energy band in type-I, and both electrons and holes flow from the broadband to the narrowband. The two semiconductor energy bands are interleaved in type-II, with photo-generated electrons and holes moving in opposite directions. And in type-III, the valence band of one semiconductor is located above the conduction band of another semiconductor, and there is no common energy in the forbidden band. In contrast, type-II heterojunctions have stronger charge carrier transfer efficiency and can achieve effective spatial separation and utilization of electron-hole under photoexcitation. But their optimal conduction band and valence band potentials are not utilized. Based on this, the researchers proposed a Z-type catalyst structure (Fig. 6(d)) [73,74]- consisting of a hydrogen-producing photocatalyst (PSI), an oxygen-producing photocatalyst (PSII), and a redox electric pair. In the photocatalytic reduction process, the conduction band electrons of PSII are transferred to the valence band holes of PSI through redox pairs, while the conduction band electrons of PSI and valence band holes of PSII are enriched separately. These heterojunction catalysts possess strong redox ability while reducing the semiconductor photogenerated electron-hole complex. It has been found that even without an electron mediator, we can achieve a Z-type catalyst electron transfer path by selecting a suitable semiconductor [75]. There are many materials currently used to construct heterojunctions to enhance the catalytic performance of Cu2O, such as TiO2 [41,76–78], Fe2O3 [42], BiVO4 [71], WO3 [79], reduced graphene oxide [43] and organic backbone [80]. Fig. 7 shows the schematic diagram of the energy band structure of each semiconductor catalytic material. The matching energy band structure is the key to achieve CO2 reduction and H2O oxidation. The semiconductors with good visible light response and excellent oxidation ability of valence band holes are not less than excellent materials for forming heterojunctions with Cu2O. That is, the position of its valence band favouring the oxidation of H2O and the position of the conduction band of Cu2O favouring the reduction of CO2 are of interest. By fully utilizing the advantages of both semiconductors, the redox capability and stability of the catalyst can be enhanced to achieving both CO2 reduction and H2O oxidation. Currently, for the Cu2O-catalyzed CO2RR, the study of heterojunction catalysts focuses on C1 products (CO, CH4 and CH3OH). Ⅰ The reaction of CO2 to CO. Cu2O/Ti2O heterojunction: As a common photocatalyst, TiO2 has the advantages of stability and photo-corrosion resistance [81]. And it is widely used in CO2RR. Its wide forbidden bandwidth makes it poorly responsive to visible light. But, if a heterojunction structure is formed with Cu2O, the disadvantages of both sides can be better compensated, and the catalytic activity can be enhanced. Aguirre et al. [41] prepared octahedral Cu2O/TiO2 heterostructures and demonstrated the enhanced CO2 reduction activity of the catalyst. The CO production rate of this catalyst (RCO = 2.11μmol·gcat −1h−1) is four times higher than that of pure Cu2O under UV-Vis light ( Fig. 8(a)). And the Z scheme mechanism can fully utilize the valence band potential of TiO2 for the oxidation of H2O (Fig. 8(b)). α-Fe2O3/Cu2O heterojunction: α-Fe2O3 has a band gap width of 2.2 eV that responds well to visible light and a valence band position at 2.48 eV that favours the oxidation of H2O [82]. But the conduction band position is not favourable for the reduction of CO2. Its energy band structure is exactly complementary to Cu2O, and the composite will be an efficient photocatalyst. As shown in Fig. 8(c), Wang et al. [42] prepared α-Fe2O3/Cu2O catalysts by hydrothermal deposition, which achieved effective separation of photo-generated electrons and holes. The authors showed that the Cu/Fe ratio affects the CO yield. And the highest CO yield of 5.0 μmol·gcat -1 was obtained for the catalyst with 50% Cu content after 3 h of visible light irradiation (Fig. 8(d)). In addition, the detection of hydroxyl radicals confirmed that α-Fe2O3/Cu2O was a Z-scheme heterojunction, as the results indicated that the catalyst achieved the reduction of H2O at the same time. BVO/C/Cu2O heterojunction: Bismuth nanomaterials have also attracted extensive attention in recent years, especially the ternary metal oxide BiVO4, which has a similar forbidden bandwidth to α-Fe2O3. It is also an excellent photocatalyst for H2O oxidation [83]. Kim et al. [71] constructed BVO/C/Cu2O catalysts based on 3D Cu2O nanowire arrays (NWAs) on a reticular substrate. As shown in Fig. 8(e), Cu2O nanowires have efficient photo-generated electron-hole transport efficiency due to their large specific surface area. While BiVO4 particles and conducting carbon act as water oxidation photocatalysts and electron mediators, respectively. The BVO/C/Cu2O catalyst was a typical Z-type heterojunction with high redox potential and low photo-generated electron-hole complexation rate. And its CO generation rate (3.01 μmol·g-1·h-1) increased exponentially (Fig. 8(f)). Also because of the protection of the carbon layer, the catalyst maintained 98% of the initial conversion performance after five cycles (Fig. 8(g)). Cu2O/WO3 heterojunction: WO3 with a medium band gap (2.4-2.7 eV) and high oxidation capacity of valence band cavities has also been used to construct heterojunctions with Cu2O. Shi et al. [79] prepared Cu2O/WO3-001 and Cu2O/WO3 Z-type heterojunction catalysts with and without the main (0 0 1) crystal facet. They investigated the CO2 reduction performance of the catalysts in the presence of water vapour under visible light. It was shown that the (0 0 1) crystal facet of WO3 nanosheets can achieve the oxidation of H2O during the reaction (Fig. 8(h)), illustrating the importance of the crystal facet in the reaction process. The maximum yield of CO for the Cu2O/WO3-001 catalyst was 11.7 μmol, and it still had good catalytic performance after four cycles (Fig. 8(i)- (j)). PFC-45/Cu2O@CP heterojunction: Several of the materials mentioned above are oxide semiconductors. In addition, catalysts with non-homogeneous structures with excellent charge transfer efficiency have attracted attention in recent years. Among them, hydrogen-bonded organic frameworks are porous materials with high specific surface area and well-defined structures. As shown in Fig. 8(k), Zhang et al. [80] prepared a thin film catalyst (PFC-45/Cu2O@CP) by depositing porphyrin hydrogen-bonded organic framework (PFC-45) and Cu2O on carbon paper by electrophoretic deposition. The formation of heterojunctions and the presence of carbon paper greatly enhanced the efficiency of photo-generated electron-hole separation. And the structure of the film improved the visible light absorption of the catalyst. The catalyst exhibited high catalytic activity (11.81 μmol·g-1·h-1) and selectivity (99%) (Fig. 8(l)). In general, all the above materials effectively improve the photocatalytic performance of CO2 reduction. Among them, the PFC-45/Cu2O@CP catalyst has the highest CO generation rate, and next is the BVO/C/Cu2O catalyst. Both are ternary catalysts with the presence of an electron mediator C. And both carbon paper in PFC-45/Cu2O@CP and Cu2O nanowires in BVO/C/C/Cu2O provide large specific surface area, which further increases the catalytic performance of the material. The intrinsic kinetics of these catalysts in the above experimental studies has not yet been resolved. By comparing the yield alone, it can be seen that PFC-45/Cu2O@CP and BVO/C/Cu2O have a better reactivity, attributed to their large reaction area and higher mass transfer efficiencies. Ⅱ The reaction of CO2 to CH4. CH4 is the main component of natural gas, and it can store more chemical energy compared to CO. As an important fuel, it is significant to improve the selectivity of CH4 products. Ag/Cu2O@rGO heterojunction: Plasma metals (Ag [84,85], Au [86]) have a good CO generation ability attributed to their intermediate binding strength. By forming a composite with Cu2O, it facilitates the next reaction of the intermediate CO and can be used as an energy donor. As shown in Fig. 9(a), Tang et al. [43] prepared Ag/Cu2O@rGO catalysts. Among them, graphene oxide (GO) is rich in active sites due to the unique functional groups on the surface (surface extended Π-bonds) [87–89]. That can further improve the transport and utilization of photo-generated electrons. The catalyst exhibited an excellent CH4 production rate (82.6 μmol·g-1·h-1) and selectivity (95.4%). Fig. 9(b) shows a schematic diagram of the mechanism for the conversion of CO2 to CH4. The density functional theory (DFT) calculations showed that the protonation of the intermediate *CO is the key step in the selective catalytic reduction of CO2 to CH4. Cu2O/TiO2 heterojunction: Ali et al. [92] prepared reduced TiO2-Cu2O Z-type heterojunction catalyst (RT-Cu2O), which effectively inhibited the photo-corrosion of Cu2O. Meanwhile, RT has more excellent photocatalytic properties because of Ti3+ and Ov defects [93,94]. The reaction was carried out in a continuous flow photoreactor, which allowed the continuous generation of CH4. And the catalyst remained stable after 7 cycles (42 h). As shown in Fig. 9(c), Yang et al. [90] prepared Cu2O/TiO2 composite nanorods by chemical reduction method. The CH4 yield was as high as 1.35 μmol·g-1·h-1 within 4 h irradiation, which was 15 and 3.07 times higher than that of Cu2O and TiO2 alone, respectively (Fig. 9(d)-(e)). The enhanced reaction yield was attributed to the formation of p-n heterojunctions that inhibited the complexation of photo-generated carriers. And the effective utilization of photo-generated electrons and holes prevented photo-corrosion of the catalysts. Therefore, the stability of the catalyst was enhanced. Cu /Cu2O heterojunction: As shown in Fig. 9(f), Zhou et al. [91] prepared a metallic Cu-Cu2O heterojunction (Cu2O@Cu), which can reduce CO2 to CH4 and part of C2H4 by a simple in situ reduction method. Among them, Cu2O was a one-dimensional nanorod, which guaranteed excellent visible light collection capability. The presence of in situ generated Cu enhanced the conductivity and photo-generated carrier transport ability of the catalyst. The CH4 yield of this catalyst was four times higher than that of pure Cu2O (Fig. 9(g)), and the C2H4 yield increased only 1.46 times (Fig. 9(h)). Moreover, the catalyst remained stable after several cycles. This study is also the first in situ method to synthesize metal-semiconductor heterojunctions with efficient catalytic performance, which provides a useful reference for the future development of photocatalysts. Among the above materials, the CH4 yield of Ag/Cu2O@rGO catalyst was as high as 82.6 μmol·g-1·h-1, while Cu2O/TiO2 was only 1.35 μmol·g-1·h-1. The reason is that Ag has a high CO generation capacity. CO as an important intermediate in CO2RR, its generation and conversion have important effects on other hydrocarbon products. Ⅲ The reaction of CO2 to CH3OH. Compared to CO and CH4, CH3OH is a clean liquid fuel and an intermediate for the synthesis of important chemicals. The conversion of CO2 to CH3OH has attracted increasing attention. Cu2O/TiO2 heterojunction: TiO2, a common photocatalytic material, has also been used in the reaction of CO2 to CH3OH. Compared to TiO2 particles, TiO2 nanotube arrays (TNTs) have greater specific surface area and charge transport properties. Earliest, Wang et al. [76] prepared Cu2O/TiO2 composite nanotube heterojunctions (Cu2O/TNT). The formation of heterojunctions drives the effective separation of photo-generated electrons and holes. And the results showed that Cu2O/TNT exhibited high CH3OH catalytic activity. Later, Li et al. [95] prepared a ternary Cu2O-graphene-TiO2 nanotube catalyst (Cu2O/rGO/TNA) based on a binary catalyst. Graphene as an electron conductor enhanced the transfer of photo-generated electrons. And a double-chamber reactor driven by light has been developed. As shown in Fig. 10(a), the oxidation of H2O occurred at the light-irradiated side, while the reduction of CO2 occurred at the backlit side. This further limited the compounding of photo-generated electrons and holes. The reverse reaction was also prevented because of the separation of the active site. The methanol yield of this catalyst was 45 μmol·g-1·h-1, which was much higher than the other binary catalysts (Fig. 10(b)). Cu2O/PCN heterojunction: Polymeric carbon nitride (PCN) is a very excellent metal-free semiconductor for photocatalytic CO2RR. It has a better visible light response and reduction capacity [97,98]. For example, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) is a very familiar photocatalyst that has been widely studied. Recently, Tian et al. [96] prepared polymerized carbon nitride - cuprous oxide catalyst (Cu2O/PCN), which can be used for the conversion of CO2 into pure water. As shown in Fig. 10(c), the yield of CH3OH was 276 μmol/g in 8 h, with a high selectivity of 100%. The optimal path was given by DFT calculation. Fig. 10(d)-(e) shows the schematic diagram of the energy distribution and reaction mechanism of the reaction intermediate. Ultimately its shows that the formation of CH3OH is more favourable than CO and HCOOH on this catalyst. Few Cu2O-based heterojunction materials are currently available for the reaction of CO2 to CH3OH. Similarly, Cu2O/rGO/TNA catalysts containing electron conductors have the best CH3OH yields, again illustrating the importance of efficient photogenerated electron transport in photocatalysis. Also, the double-chamber reactor provides inspiration for the design of catalytic reactors. It prevents the photo-generated electron-hole complex and the reverse reaction to some extent. In general, the construction of heterojunctions is mainly through reducing the photo-generated electron-hole complex and making full use of the valence band/conduction band positions of both semiconductors as well as their respective advantages to form catalysts with stronger redox capability and stability. Eventually, the reduction of CO2 occurs on Cu2O and the reduction of H2O on another semiconductor. The efficient transfer of charge is the key to the reaction. Suitable material combinations can improve heterojunction efficiency. Matching energy band structures can promote charge transfer utilization, e.g., material combinations with similar energy band widths can have less electron-hole scattering, thus improving photocatalytic efficiency. The metal oxides mentioned in the paper (e.g., TiO2, Fe2O3, BiVO4) all have matched energy level structures with Cu2O and can form Z-type heterojunctions. The conduction band electrons of the other metal oxide are transferred to the valence band holes of Cu2O, so that the valence band holes of the other metal oxides and the conduction band electrons of Cu2O get aggregated to have a strong redox capacity. Some of these heterogeneous structures contain electronic conductors that can better facilitate the utilization of charge transport. For the metal-Cu2O heterostructure, the presence of metal enhances the electrical conductivity and photogenerated carrier transport ability of the catalyst, and facilitates the utilization of charge transport at the interface. The presence of the Schottky barrier effectively prevents the photogenerated electron-hole complexation. And for ternary heterostructures, one of the components is usually used to act as an electron conductor to further improve the transport efficiency of the photogenerated carriers. This can be a carbon material or a metal material, which effectively traps the photogenerated electrons by improving the electrical conductivity of the catalysts or by forming an electron trap effect. In conclusion, the construction of heterojunctions is an effective strategy to improve photocatalytic performance. Although the product generation rate and the stability of Cu2O were improved, they were concentrated on the C1 product. Further research and development are needed for the generation of the C2+ product. 3.2.3 Carbon-based composites The study of heterojunctions revealed that composite catalysts containing carbonaceous materials have more efficient photocatalytic activity, such as BVO/C/Cu2O catalysts containing conductive carbon [71], PFC-45/Cu2O catalysts deposited on carbon paper [80], Ag/Cu2O catalysts coated by rGO [43], and ternary Cu2O/rGO/TNA catalysts with rGO as the electron conductor [95]. The presence of carbonaceous materials promotes the efficient transfer and utilization of charge carriers, reduces the compounding rate of photo-generated electrons and holes. It can transfer electrons to the surface for CO2 reduction in time before they react with Cu2O, avoiding the occurrence of Cu2O photo-corrosion. In addition, carbonaceous materials generally have a large specific surface area. The uniform dispersion of the catalyst on this material improves the visible light absorption of the catalyst and provides a larger reaction site and more active sites. Therefore, by combining Cu2O-based catalysts with highly conductive materials such as carbonaceous materials, the photocatalytic activity of Cu2O materials can be greatly promoted, which is of great research significance. 3.2.4 Metal deposition Besides constructing heterojunctions, metal loading can also effectively solve the disadvantages of single semiconductor catalysts, such as poor light absorption ability, easy photo-generated electron-hole complexation and poor stability [99–102]. The photo-generated electron-hole complexation is the main reason for the low photocatalytic activity of Cu2O. And the loaded metal can effectively trap the charge carriers and suppress this unfavourable complexation. This is because by loading metal catalysts, Schottky barriers can be effectively constructed. Photo-generated electrons can flow from the semiconductor surface to the loading metal through the Schottky junction, reducing the complexation of holes. Also, the efficient utilization of charge carriers improves the light corrosion resistance of Cu2O. In addition, anchoring the metal as a co-catalyst to the semiconductor surface not only generates more active sites, but also creates a synergistic effect with the semiconductor. This will affect the adsorption behaviour of the intermediate and the activation potential of the reaction, prompting the reaction to occur. Zhang et al. [103] prepared Pd-modified Cu2O photocatalysts. Pd is widely used in CO2RR, which exhibits high selectivity for CO and formate [104]. The presence of Pd was shown to increase the charge mobility and photo-corrosion resistance of the catalyst. CO is the only product, and the yield increases exponentially in the Pd/Cu2O (100). However, the change in catalyst performance cannot be achieved at the Cu2O (111). Because the (111) facet has a relatively low work function ( Fig. 11(a)-(b)), which does not allow the charge transfer between Pd and Cu2O. The authors also demonstrated by BET and CO2 adsorption experiments that the introduction of Pd also enhanced the adsorption energy of CO2. The activation of CO2 adsorption is a key step of the reaction and has a significant impact. Overall, the results of this study suggest that the selection of exposed crystal facets and the charge migration between them and the loaded metals contribute to the reduction of CO2. Deng et al. [105] demonstrated that loading Cu0 on the Cu2O(111) facet accelerated the carrier separation efficiency and avoided photo-corrosion of the catalyst. This further increased the yield (78.4 μmol·g-1·h-1) and selectivity (97%) of CH4. It is suggested that the interface with a mixed Cu state improved the catalyst activity because of its high conductivity. Moreover, the authors showed that the Cu2O (111) facet allowed the selective catalytic conversion of CO2 to CH4, while the yield of CH4 in the (100) facet is negligible. The above two works also illustrated that the choice of crystal facets has an important effect on the reaction. The difference in the work function of different facets affects the electron energy band structure and the charge separation. In addition, plasma catalysis holds very good promise [106]. It can generate charge carriers with high kinetic energy and significantly improve photocatalytic efficiency and reaction activity [107–109]. Al, as a typical plasma metal, has outstanding optical properties [110]. Le et al. [111] investigated the mechanism of direct CO2 dissociation induced by plasma Al@Cu2O core-shell structure using DFT calculations. As shown in Fig. 11(c), the CO2 dissociation potential was reduced from 3.6 eV to 1.4 eV under photon excitation. And the reaction rate was significantly higher, allowing direct dissociation at relatively low temperature and ambient pressure. The catalyst had a higher selectivity for CO than CH4. The study demonstrates the positive role of plasma in CO2RR and suggests that Ag can also be used as a plasma core for CO2 reduction on Cu2O, providing a new idea for the development and utilization of catalysts. 3.2.5 Elemental doping It has been shown that Cu2O near-surface defects can capture photo-generated charges and thus facilitate the separation of photo-generated charges, providing a strong driving force [112]. Elemental doping, as a typical point defect, refers to the introduction of other elements into the Cu2O lattice. It affects the energy band structure of the catalyst or causes lattice distortion. And it is a simple method used to enhance photocatalytic activity and semiconductor photosensitization. For semiconductors such as TiO2 and ZnO, which have wider bandgap widths, they can only absorb ultraviolet light from sunlight and are less responsive to visible light. The main purpose of elemental doping is to adjust their energy band structure to give them improved visible light absorption [113,114]. In comparison, for Cu2O, the material itself has a better visible light response and a conduction band position favourable for CO2 reduction. Therefore, the main purpose of doping is to reduce the photo-generated electron-hole complexation rate of the catalyst and increase the charge carrier mobility thus improving the photocatalytic activity. The anion (F, Cl, N) doping can significantly improve the photocatalytic performance of the material. Yu et al. [49] prepared a Cl-doped Cu2O nanorod. Cl doping modulates the energy band structure of Cu2O, enabling the reduction of CO2 and oxidation of H2O over a single catalyst. And the catalyst exhibits enhanced CO2RR activity. As shown in Fig. 12(a), the Cl doping optimized the energy band structure of Cu2O. The doped catalyst has a relatively high valence band position, which can realize the reduction of CO2 and the oxidation of H2O simultaneously. It could realize CO2 reduction and water oxidation simultaneously. Cl doping also improved the catalyst conductivity, which enhanced the CO2 adsorption capacity and the separation transfer efficiency of photo-generated carriers. The catalyst had good CH4 yield and selectivity (Fig. 12(b)-(c)) and maintained some stability after several cycles (Fig. 12(d)). It was shown by DFT calculations that the Cl-doped Cu2O facilitated the conversion of CO2 to intermediates * COOH, *CO and *CH3O compared to the pure Cu2O catalyst (Fig. 12 (e)). This reduced the difficulty of the reaction and enhanced the CO and CH4 generation activity. That is, in addition to the enhancement of catalytic activity, doping also forms new active sites that affect the adsorption behaviour of intermediates, thus promoting the improvement of product selectivity. For the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 by Cu2O, the biggest problem lies in solving its photo-generated electron-hole easy complexation and photo-corrosion, and the above methods have been effectively tried with excellent results. The compounding rate of photo-generated electrons and holes is reduced mainly by introducing a second component or a protective layer, which improves catalyst stability while providing more active sites. 3.3 Mechanistic study of Cu2O-based photocatalysts Based on the study of 3.2, we found that for photocatalysis, currently, the products are concentrated on the C1 products (CO, CH4, CH3OH). Catalysts with higher CO binding energy are expected to generate CH4/CH3OH value-added products, and the stronger binding energy promotes the next step of CO conversion. Tang et al. [43] prepared Ag/Cu2O composite catalysts in which the presence of Ag provided high CO coverage and the favourable protonation of *CO in the reaction was essential for the generation of CH4. Tian et al. [96] prepared a Cu2O/PCN catalyst, which showed that the thermodynamic potential barriers for the formation of *CHO from *CO on this catalyst were lower than those for *COH and desorption, facilitating its subsequent formation of CH3OH. Yu et al. [49] prepared Cl-doped Cu2O catalysts, where doping promoted the reduction of CO2 to the intermediates * COOH, *CO, and *CH3O, and in particular the lowering of the potential barrier of *CH3OH, which facilitated the generation of CH4. In summary, for the generation of the C1 product, which does not involve a C-C coupling process and has a relatively simple reaction pathway, it lies mainly in the competition between the *CO desorption and protonation processes. Stronger *CO adsorption energies and lower protonation reaction barriers are essential for the generation of the multivalent products CH4 and CH3OH. We can predict the desorption energy and protonation potential of *CO on the catalyst based on DFT calculations, which helps us to develop efficient catalysts. Based on the above literature research, for Cu2O, the common products are CO, CH4, and CH3OH. And based on different modification strategies and reaction conditions, the yields of CO are concentrated around 1.5∼12 μmolgcat −1h−1; CH4 yields up to 80 μmolgcat −1h−1; the yields of CH3OH are around 34∼45 μmolgcat −1h−1. Based on a single Cu2O catalyst, the yields increased exponentially. For other photocatalysts, TiO2 [115], experimental studies have shown that its CO yields are concentrated around 0.15∼14.54 μmolgcat −1h−1, which is about the same as that on Cu2O; and the CH4 yields are mainly concentrated around 1∼23 μmolgcat −1h−1 which is lower than that on Cu2O, but one study showed that a one-dimensional structured TiO2-loaded Pt nanoparticle catalyst showed a CH4 yield as high as 1361 μmolgcat −1h−1 [116], which is much higher than that of the other catalysts; the yields of CH3OH are concentrated around 10 μmolgcat −1h−1, which is lower than that on Cu2O. For metal sulfides [117], the CO yields ranged from tens to hundreds to thousands of μmolgcat −1h−1 with good CO generating capacity; CH4 yields are concentrated below 10 μmolgcat −1h−1, much lower than those on Cu2O; and CH3OH yields are concentrated below 10 μmolgcat −1h−1, lower than those on Cu2O, but the Bi2S3- and CdS-based catalysts show yields as high as around 134 and 145 μmolgcat −1h−1. For the carbon nitride-based catalysts [118], they also have high CO generation yields of 54, 77.8 and 188 μmolgcat −1h−1, but their CH4 and CH3OH yields are both much lower than those on Cu2O, which are basically below 5 μmolgcat −1h−1. Overall, the yield of CO on Cu2O is not as good as the other three catalysts compared to the other catalysts, but it is more dominant for the generation of CH4 and CH3OH, which is more attractive. The ability to generate C1 products on the Cu2O has been improved, but we still need to work on the selective generation of C2+ products. Further development is needed to find more efficient and stable Cu2O-based photocatalysts. 4 Research status of Cu2O electrocatalytic CO2 reduction Electrocatalytic CO2RR is simple in operation, mild in conditions, and has diverse reduction products [119,120]. Moreover, electrocatalysis can be powered by clean energy sources such as solar, wind and geothermal, which are green and environmentally friendly. It can realize the effective use of renewable energy in CO2 reduction and provide a broad prospect for its large-scale industrial application [121]. For example, electrocatalysis can be based on photocatalysis by using an optical semiconductor as an electrode and applying a little bias voltage to achieve the separation of electron-hole. This effectively improves the shortcomings of photo-generated electron-hole complexation. However, the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 is still challenging, due to the chemical inertness of the CO2 molecule, complex multi-electron processes, and the competing HER. This produces many disadvantages of CO2 electrochemical reactions as the following: high reaction potentials, low FE due to competing side reactions, and low selectivity for a given product due to a plurality of formed products [122]. In addition, the following factors limit its practical application in industry. First, the stability of current catalysts still does not meet industrial requirements. Second, the current density of the C2 product is lower relative to the C1 product during the reaction. Third, it is usually at higher overpotentials that the reaction can produce a higher FE. Therefore, the development of efficient, cheap and easily available electrocatalysts has become the focus of CO2 electroreduction. 4.1 Advantages and shortcomings of Cu2O for electrocatalytic CO2RR 4.1.1 Advantages Early studies on electrocatalytic electrodes focused on metal electrodes, and Hori et al. [123] classified metal catalysts into four categories based on CO2 reduction products: (1) Au, Ag, Pd, Ga, Zn, which mainly produce CO; (2) Bi, Pb, Sn, Cd, Hg, In, Tl, which mainly produce formate; (3) Cu and Cu alloys, which can produce C2 products; (4) Ni, Ti, Pt, Fe, which favours the HER reaction. The unique properties of copper-based catalysts are thus revealed, mainly in the suitable CO binding energy and the generation of multicarbon products [124]. Various copper-based catalysts have been developed to improve the disadvantages of metallic copper such as high overpotential, slow kinetics and low stability [58]. Among them, Cu2O is of interest because of its high FE of C2 products (C2H4, C2H5OH) [15–17]. Compared to bulk flat metallic copper, Cu2O has a higher specific surface area, providing more active sites and a surface rich in defects. First, it has been shown that Cu2O has a stronger CO binding energy compared to metallic copper [15] and inhibits the CO protonation process [16], resulting in a stronger C2 product generation. Secondly, for Cu2O, its surface is prone to low-coordinated copper atoms during electrochemical processes, often in a mixed state of Cu0-Cu+, which synergistically have improved catalytic properties [20,54,55]. Yao et al. [125] showed that Cu2O formed low-coordinated surface Cu atoms during electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. DFT calculations showed that the adsorption capacity of Cu atoms for CO and COH was enhanced with a lower number of atom coordination. It has also been previously shown that low-coordinated copper atoms favour CO adsorption [126] and CO hydrogenation to CHO [127]. And for Yao's study, the CO-COH coupling barrier decreased with decreasing coordination number, which was more favourable than the CO-CO coupling mode. The FE of the C2 product was as high as 77.8% (-0.69 V, 300 mA/cm2) under alkaline conditions. Overall, Cu2O exhibits a great potential for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. 4.1.2 Limitations First, CO2 activation to generate intermediate *CO2 - requires a high reaction potential and energy [128]. The higher activation potential increases the difficulty of the electrocatalytic reaction. Second, the products of electrochemical reduction reaction are highly dependent on the applied voltage [6]. Due to the presence of multiple adjacent reaction intermediates and complex proton-coupled electron transfer in CO2RR, the product species are sometimes not homogeneous and need to be further isolated. We can adjust the adsorption behaviour of the reaction intermediates and optimize the reaction path by modifying the catalyst to promote the selective generation of a single product. Third, Cu2O is easily reduced during the reaction process, and although Cu2O that generates low-coordinated copper atoms on the surface has an improved ability to generate C2 products, too much or too little of it affects the activity of CO2RR, resulting in reduced catalytic performance [24]. We need to optimize the number of low-ligand copper atoms to prevent catalyst deactivation. Finally, due to the close onset potentials, the HER is a common competitive side reaction in the CO2RR process [129]. Further improvement of the selectivity of high-value products on Cu2O-based catalysts by inhibiting the HER through modification of the catalysts is the focus of electrocatalytic CO2RR. 4.2 Strategies for building efficient Cu2O-based electrocatalysts 4.2.1 Morphology and crystal facet modulation I Morphological modulation. The morphological structure of the catalyst has an important influence on the CO2 reduction performance of the material. Morphology modulation achieves changes in catalyst performance by affecting the reaction area, mass transfer rate and active sites. It can effectively improve the FE of C2 products on Cu2O catalysts. Different structures have their own advantages. The common types of catalyst structures with high performance are mainly thin film structures, porous structures, and nano-cavity and core-shell structures. Film structure: Thin film catalysts with uniformly distributed structures have higher stability than powder catalysts that tend to agglomerate. And the grain boundaries on the surface of the film facilitate the improvement of C2 product selectivity. First, the presence of grain boundaries not only promotes the transport and utilization of electron, but also leads to changes in the local electric field. It also provides more active sites, which affects the adsorption behaviour of the reactive intermediates and promotes the dimerization of the C1 intermediates [130]. Secondly, the Cu2O film is easily reduced to generate Cu0 during the reaction process, forming a Cu+-Cu0 interface at the grain boundary. The synergistic effect of Cu+-Cu0 enhances the adsorption of *CO and lowers the reaction barrier, thus facilitating the C-C coupling reaction [131]. Overall, the grain boundaries on the surface of thin films can effectively improve the performance of catalysts, but we need more theoretical and experimental studies to understand the mechanism of their influence. In addition, there are various methods for thin film preparation, including electrophoretic deposition, where layers of different thicknesses can be easily formed by varying time and voltage. Ren et al. [24] prepared Cu2O thin films with different coverage thicknesses (0-8.8 μm) by electrodeposition. As can be seen in Fig. 13(a)-(d), the yield of CH4 was significantly reduced on all the Cu2O thin film catalysts. Among them, the 1.7 μm-thick catalyst has the highest FE of C2 (39% for C2H4 and 9% for C2H5OH, at 0.99 V), while the HER becomes favourable on the 8.8 μm-thick catalyst. This is due to the fact that it has an excess of ligand-unsaturated copper atoms on its surface, resulting in stronger binding to hydrogen atoms. And the study indicates that the film thickness greatly affects the reaction selectivity. Fig. 13(e) showed a schematic diagram of the mechanistic model for the reduction of CO2 to C2H4/C2H5OH. It involves the generation of the intermediate *CO and its continued hydrogenation to CH4 or dimerization-hydrogenation to C2HxO2, and C2HxO2 is further reduced to C2H4/C2H5OH. For the generation of C2H4/C2H5OH, *CH2CHO is an important common reaction intermediate. The higher FE for C2H4 in this study is attributed to the energetically favourable hydrogenation of *CH2CHO to C2H4. In addition to the effect of pH at the electrode surface, the optimized edge and step densities on this Cu2O thin-film catalyst are also critical for the dimerization of the reaction intermediates. In addition, the authors refer to studies that suggest a kinetically more favourable C-C coupling process if the direct reactant is *CHO / *CH2O rather than *CO. That is, the direct dimerization of *CO is slow and has a high reaction potential. In contrast, the first hydrogenation of *CO to form *CHO and the subsequent reaction with the other hydrogenation product (*CHxO) is kinetically more favourable [132]. That is, as also mentioned before, other C-C coupling schemes show more favourable advantages. Porous structure: The nanometer-sized dendritic porous structure can increase the reaction area, improve the current transfer efficiency and the CO2 mass transfer efficiency. And it can optimize the selectivity and activity of the reaction by affecting the adsorption behaviour of the intermediates. Feroze et al. [135] prepared Cu2O electrodes with a dendritic structure. In addition to the increase of the active surface, its rough and porous structure changed the adsorption properties of the intermediate. The results showed that the presence of this structure enhanced the stability of the catalyst and the selectivity of the C2H4 product. Nanocavity and core-shell structures: Such structures can directly or indirectly stabilize the active species Cu+ by controlling it in a certain region and preventing it from being reduced, thus facilitating the C-C coupling reaction [136]. Yang et al. [133] prepared a multi-cavity structure of Cu2O and showed that the in situ generated carbon intermediates were confined within the Cu2O cavity. The increased intermediate coverage prevented the reduction of the active species Cu+ and improved the possibility of C-C coupling (Fig. 13(f)). The FE of the C2 product of this structured Cu2O catalyst was up to more than 75%. Cheng et al. [134] also considered Cu+ as the active species for the generation of C2 products from CO2RR. And they suggested that the suitable binding energy and the stability of Cu+ on the Cu2O surface are crucial for the high selectivity of C2 products. Therefore, they prepared Cu2O@K-PBA core-shell structured electrocatalysts and showed that the K-PBA shell layer protected the Cu2O active nucleus (Fig. 13(g)). And due to the formation of a dipole field, the adsorption energy of the intermediate with dipole moment was enhanced. In other words, the change of the inherent adsorption energy of Cu2O promoted the formation of C2 products while inhibiting the production of CH4. II crystal facet modulation. Metal oxide surfaces have a more complex morphological structure than metals. The crystal faces exposed on the metal oxide particles not only determine the surface geometry but also strongly influence the selective generation of intermediates during the reaction. This is manifested by the presence of different active sites, surface structures, and atomic bond lengths on different crystal facets, which have different absorption/desorption energies for intermediates [137–139]. A deeper understanding of the active crystal facet and catalytic sites of crystals is of great importance for catalyst performance enhancement. A lot of work has been carried out to investigate the activity and selectivity of reactions on different crystal facets of Cu2O. Single crystal facet study: Fu et al. [40] prepared Cu2O nanoparticles with different morphologies and crystal facets. As shown in Fig. 14(a), abundant crystal defects/grain boundaries were observed on the reconstructed concave octahedral Cu2O surface with high index crystal facets, which may act as an active site for C-C coupling. And the reaction process would generate Cu2O nanocrystals with a smaller size to achieve efficient production of C2+ by CO2 reduction. Zhang et al. [18] also prepared hollow Cu2O with abundant defects and step facets (Fig. 14(b)). The authors showed by DFT calculations that the high index crystal facet of Cu2O and the high CO coverage on the surface are favourable for C-C coupling. In addition to the C2 product, it also has a high FE for n-propanol (8.21%). The above work shows that high index crystal facets contain a large number of grain boundaries and unsaturated atoms, resulting in high catalytic activity. Liu et al. [140] prepared Cu2O nanoparticles with different crystal facets by hydrothermal method, including Cu2O-c (cubic structure with (100) crystal facets), Cu2O-o (octahedral structure with (111) crystal facets), Cu2O-t (truncated octahedral structure with (100) and (111) crystal facets) and Cu2O-u (sea urchin-like structure with (100), (220) and (222) crystal facets), indicating that the (111) facet favours the reduction of CO2 to alcohol (Fig. 14(c)). The crystal facet-dependent effect is related to the oxygen vacancy concentration, the CO2 reduction energy barrier and the different Cu-O bond lengths on each crystal facet. As shown in Fig. 14(d), among the constructed Cu2O nanoparticles, the octahedral structure Cu2O-o with (111) crystal facet had the highest total FE (35.4%) for the alcohol product. This is due to the abundant oxygen defects and short Cu2O bonds on the (111) crystal facet that confer lower activation potential and kinetic barriers to the catalyst. And the surface reconfiguration of Cu2O made the catalyst rich in Cu0 and Cu+ sites, which could promote CO2 activation and CO* adsorption, thus enhancing C-C coupling. Luo et al. [141], on the other hand, showed that the Cu2O (322) crystal facet facilitates the selective generation of C2H4 with a FE of 74.1%. It was also shown by DFT calculations that the presence of (322) crystal facets can significantly reduce the Gibbs free energy in the C-C coupling process, thus significantly improving the selectivity of C2H4. Poly-crystal facet effect: Since the crystal anisotropic facets can realize the separation of charge transfer, the activity of Cu2O is effectively enhanced. And the synergistic effect between the crystal faces promotes the C-C coupling reaction and improves the selectivity of C2 products. In recent years, edge-truncated Cu2O catalysts containing multiple crystal facets have received attention in CO2RR. Gao et al. [142] investigated the effect of Cu2O nanoparticles with different morphologies ( Fig. 15(a)) on the electrocatalytic performance of CO2 to C2H4. As shown in Fig. 15(b), Cu2O with (111) and (100) crystal facets had the highest selectivity of C2H4 with a FE of 59%. This is because the Fermi energy level of Cu2O on the (111) face is lower than that on the (100) face, promoting the charge transfer between the Cu2O (111) and (100) faces. And it further promoted the multi-electron correlation kinetics of ethylene production. The above studies show that the modulation of the catalyst morphology and crystal facets can not only enhance the reaction activity but also significantly improve the selectivity of C2 products. For CO2 reactions with similar product reduction potentials, this strategy is very advantageous. And it is often used for electrode modulation in electrocatalytic reactions. If morphology and crystal facet modulation are used in combination with other strategies (co-catalysts or doping, etc.), more active sites can be provided. By modulating the adsorption behaviour of the reaction intermediates to have lower reaction barriers, and the reaction can also achieve higher FE at lower overpotentials. 4.2.2 Metal deposition It has been mentioned previously that metal loading can realize the separation and utilization of photo-generated electron-hole in Cu2O photocatalytic CO2RR. It can effectively solve the problem of low Cu2O photocatalytic performance. Facing the problems of high reduction potential, low energy conversion efficiency, poor selectivity and obvious competitive HER in the Cu2O electrocatalytic CO2RR, metal loading is still an effective strategy. In addition to the increase of electrical conductivity and active sites, it was shown that metals and semiconductors create synergistic effects that make possible the occurrence of complex CO2RR. This synergistic effect influenced the adsorption behaviour of the intermediates of the electrochemical reaction process and contributed to the selective generation of C2 products. Earlier, Won et al. [34] showed that loading metals catalysts on CuO/Cu2O thin films can effectively enhance the FE of CO2 conversion to fuel ( Fig. 16(a)). Later, many more studies have been carried out for the reduction of CO2 by Cu2O loaded transition metals. The type of transition metal largely determines the selectivity of the product. The following are some of the studies on the application of transition metal (TM)-Cu2O catalysts in CO2RR. Ni-Cu2O catalysts: It has been previously shown that Cu2O and Ni deposited on the surface of tin-doped indium oxide (ITO) can promote the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in alkaline solutions [145]. The Ni-Cu2O composite catalyst would be a promising bifunctional catalyst for CO2RR and OER that is of interest. Pan et al. [44] prepared a bifunctional Ni-Cu2O electrocatalyst using electrodeposition, and it was the first reported bifunctional catalyst for CO2RR and OER. When the applied potential was switched between oxidizing and reducing conditions, the CO2RR and OER could be realized at the same electrode. The synergistic effect between Ni and Cu2O and the presence of a porous carbon substrate maximize the bimetallic active site for CO2 reduction, improving the FE of the formate and CO. At the same time, the current density of the OER increases exponentially. Ag/Cu2O catalysts: More studies have also been carried out for metal Ag-Cu composites. It is well known that transition metal Ag catalysts have high selectivity for CO [84,85], and the high coverage of CO is favourable for C-C coupling to generate C2 products. At the same time, the HER is inhibited because of the relative reduction of *H coverage. Gao et al. [45] demonstrated that Ag-covered Cu2O nanowires have high FE (76%) for C2H4 and other C2+. Both the selectivity and activity of the catalysts were effectively improved. In addition, Herzog et al. [146] uniformly loaded Ag nanoparticles on Cu2O nanocubes to study the application of Ag/Cu2O composite catalysts in electrocatalytic CO2RR. Under the same conditions, the Ag/Cu2O catalyst had double the FE of C2+ liquid fuel products (ethanol, 1-propanol and acetaldehyde) compared to the single Cu2O catalyst. And the generation of formate and H2 was inhibited, probably due to the structural rearrangement caused by the surface silver-copper alloying. The increase in the Cu-Ag atomic distance relative to the Cu-Cu distance changes the binding energy of the intermediates, which favours the formation of C2+ product alcohols/formulas. Au/Cu2O catalysts: In addition to Ag, Au metals can generate CO at low overpotentials and also show high activity for the generation of CO in electrocatalytic CO2RR [86]. That is to say, the synergistic interaction between the active centers on Ag and Au that generate CO and those on Cu2O that generate C2 further improves the selectivity of the C2 product. Earlier, Tan et al. [143] investigated the effect of cubic Cu2O@Au catalyst on electrocatalytic CO2RR. The results showed that this catalyst could improve the FE of CO by about twice as much as Cu2O and Au alone (Fig. 16(b)). The authors showed that the enhanced catalyst performance is related to the interfacial effect of the metal oxides, which enhances CO2 adsorption while facilitating charge transfer. In addition, Zhang et al. [144] prepared Aux/Cu2O composites by loading Au particles(7 nm) on hollow Cu2O nanospheres(150-180 nm). The composite catalysts significantly improved the FE of CO and C2H5OH and inhibited the HER. The increase in C2H5OH yield lies in the Au site which facilitated the formation of CO and promoted C-C coupling. Since C2H4 and C2H5OH have similar reaction pathways (Fig. 16(c)), that is, the *HOCCH to *HOCHCH hydrogenation pathway and the *HOCCH to *CCH de-hydroxylation pathway, the authors showed that the loaded metal Au content influenced the C2H4/C2H5OH ratio. After that, their research group investigated the effect of Au/Cu2O catalyst on C2H4 selectivity [147]. And the results similarly showed that the optimal Au/Cu ratio affected the effective sequential catalysis between Au and Cu2O. That can improve the selectivity of C-C coupling to C2H4 and C2H5OH, indicating that the metal loading has an important effect on the reaction products. Studies on Au/Cu2O catalysts have also shown that the structural morphology of Cu2O also affects the selectivity of the products. As shown above, the Cu2O catalysts with surface loaded metals can effectively promote the charge transfer and provide more active sites. The synergistic effect between the metal and the oxide improves the activity of the reaction and the FE of the product. Interestingly, different loading metals have different selectivity for the reaction. As in previous studies of CO2 reduction products on various pure metals, the product distribution on metal-Cu2O catalysts is strongly influenced by the loading metal. For example, the presence of Ni contributed to OER, and the Ni-Cu2O catalyst improved formate and CO selectivity, but did not promote C2 product selective generation; The presence of Ag, Au due to increase the coverage of CO, its synergistic effect with Cu2O greatly contributes to the generation of C2.
