We could start a study of other metals (e.g., Zn, Pd) that favour CO production and perhaps have promoted C2 production as well. 4.2.3 Vacancy defects and doping on the surface of Cu2O Surface defects have attracted extensive attention as important active sites for metal oxide-based catalysts. The construction of defects is an effective means to improve the catalyst performance, which affects the binding energy of key intermediates during the reaction. Point defects are generally studied mainly, and common crystal defects are vacancy defects and impurity defects (doping) [148]. Ⅰ Vacancy defect. Vacancy defects are the formation of Cu vacancies (Cuv) or O vacancies (Ov) on the surface of Cu2O, and the formation of vacancies can be controlled by changing the deposition potential with ease of operation [149]. Vacancies can modulate the electronic structure of the surrounding atoms and change the energy barrier of the rate-limiting step in the reaction [150]. The introduction of Cu vacancies will reduce the forbidden band width of Cu2O. The small forbidden band width makes it easier for electrons to be excited on the conduction band and enhances the electron transfer ability. It can effectively reduce the overpotential of the reaction and improve the activity of the electrocatalyst. Ren et al. [46] constructed Cu vacancies by etching during the synthesis of Cu2O catalysts to investigate its effect on the distribution of products in CO2RR. XPS and DOS results showed that the presence of Cuv changed the electronic structure and the forbidden band width of the catalyst. In addition, as shown in Fig. 17(a)-(b), the construction of Cuv also inhibited the occurrence of HER and generated C2H4 products with higher FE at a smaller overpotential. This is because the introduction of Cuv changed the adsorption energy of the intermediate species *CO, *CH2 and *COH on the catalyst surface (Fig. 17(c)). The suitable adsorption energy facilitated the next reaction of the intermediate products, reduced the Gibbs free energy of *CO hydrogenation and C-C coupling. Therefore, the conversion of CO2 to C2H4 was promoted. It is well demonstrated that the presence of Cuv facilitates the enhancement of the catalytic performance of Cu2O and improves the selectivity of the C2 product. For O vacancies, in previous studies, it was found that CO2 is non-activated adsorbed on the perfect surface of Cu2O. While it can be physically or chemically adsorbed on the defective surface in the form of molecules, carbonates or CO2-, and can even dissociate into CO molecules and lattice oxygen atoms to repair O vacancies [151–153]. In conclusion, the presence of O vacancies promotes the activated adsorption of CO2, which is very important for the reaction. Wang et al. [47] reported a method for combined modulation of Cu2O morphology and O vacancies by ionic liquids. The ionic liquid [Omim]Cl (1-octyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride) was used as a bifunctional structure guide to prepare Cu2O nanoparticles with a rough surface and rich in O vacancies. Among them, [Omim]+ played a role in regulating the Cu2O morphology, while Cl- led to the formation of O vacancies by coordination with Cu+. As shown in Fig. 17(d), the catalyst showed a high total FE of C2 of 78.5 ± 2% at 1.1 V. That because the presence of Ov enhanced the adsorption of the intermediate *CO and reduced the free energy of the reaction, thus promoting C-C coupling (Fig. 17(e)-(f)). Ⅱ Impurity defects. (1) Metal doping: For electrocatalytic reactions, we often achieve the improvement of electrocatalytic performance by doping with metal elements. The introduction of a second metal element can change the inherent nature of Cu2O. And the synergistic effect between metals has an positive impact on the catalytic performance and product selectivity. It can effectively solve the problems of complex CO2 electrochemical reactions and a large variety of products. Different metal doping has different effects. Baran et al. [56] showed that alkali metal doping is a combined effect of electronic and geometric effects leading to a reduction in the band gap; Zn, as donor impurities in Cu2O, can affect the lattice constant and band gap; Ag doping has a greater effect on conductivity and photocurrent density; Fe doping is beneficial to the formation of defects and the improvement of conductivity. In addition, there are many atoms used for doping, which are not listed here. The following are some applications of elemental doping on Cu2O. Ag doping：It was shown that the transition metal Ag has high selectivity for CO [84,85]. And the coverage of intermediate CO can be improved by Ag doping, which is conducive to the subsequent C-C coupling reaction. This plays an important role in improving the selectivity of C2 products. Lee et al. [154] prepared Ag-doped Cu2O catalysts, which exhibited high C2H5OH selectivity. The authors constructed catalysts with two different elemental arrangements: phase blending (Ag-Cu2OPB) and phase separation (Ag-Cu2OPS), and the addition of Ag inhibited the HER. As shown in Fig. 18(a), the FE of C2H5OH on Ag-Cu2OPB was three times higher than that of Cu2O catalyst alone. And showed that it was more efficient than the Ag-Cu2OPS, probably because of the presence of more Ag-Cu two-phase boundaries, which promoted the insertion of CO into the bond between CH2 and Cu (Fig. 18(b)). That is, the portion of Ag-Cu two-phase boundary promotes the CO-insertion reaction, which increases the C2H5OH production. This also illustrates the importance of crystal boundaries. In doping: In has very large potential, and it has been shown that the synergistic interaction between Cu-In can promote the adsorption of intermediates *COOH and inhibit the adsorption of *H, favouring the selective production of CO [157,158]. CO is used as an important chemical raw material to prepare a variety of chemicals and is also a good reducing agent. Larrazábal et al. [48] studied the effect of In, Sn, Ga, and Al element doping on the selectivity of the Cu2O-catalyzed CO2RR. The results showed that Sn and In-doped Cu2O further improved the current efficiency of CO (about 75% after 12 h at -0.6 V). In contrast, Al significantly altered the selectivity of the catalyst, reducing the selectivity for CO but facilitating the reduction of CO2 to C2H4, n-propanol and C2H5OH. Wang et al. [155] also showed that In-Cu@Cu2O catalysts can selectively electro-reduce CO2 to CO. The FE of CO generation reached 87.6 ± 2.2% (Fig. 18(c)) and the total current density was 11.1 ± 0.85 mA·cm2 at -0.8 V, which was better than most reported copper-based electrocatalysts. The reason is that the doped In content can regulate the Cu+/Cu0 ratio and charge distribution, etc., while the synergistic effect between Cu and In can enhance the adsorption of *COOH. Sb doping: Sb is gradually attracting attention for its ability to promote the selective production of CO [159]. Chen et al. [156] developed an antimony-doped Cu/Cu2O catalyst (Cu/Cu2O-Sb) for the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO. As shown in Fig. 18(d)-(e), the doping of Sb inhibited the HER and enhanced the activation of CO2. The pre-adsorbed *CO on its surface promoted the desorption of adjacent *CO, and it was the key to the selective catalytic reduction of CO2 to CO (Fig. 18(f)). (2) Non-metallic element doping. It has been suggested that the reduction of Cu+ active species is associated with the loss of lattice oxygen atoms in Cu2O [160]. The weak metal-oxygen bonds are prone to receiving electrons and breaking. Therefore, stabilizing the lattice oxygen in Cu2O is beneficial to enhance the performance of Cu2O catalysts in CO2RR. In response, Yao et al. [161] doped B in Cu2O and showed that B could effectively inhibit lattice oxygen in Cu2O, thus significantly improving the stability of Cu+. The activity and selectivity of CO2 conversion to C2H4 on B-Cu2O catalyst was enhanced and the product ratio after doping (C2H4/CO = 2.5) was 3.5 times higher than that of pure Cu2O. This was related to the formation of B-O bond and the enhancement of Cu-O bond, which gave the intermediate *CO a lower generation energy barrier and thus affects the generation of the product to C2. In addition, doping is also an effective means to optimize the adsorption behaviour of key intermediates in the CO2 reduction process. It can promote the selective generation of specific products. Ma et al. [162] investigated the effect of S doping on the reduction of CO2 by Cu2O. Experiments and DFT calculations showed that S doping reduced the generation energy of intermediate *OCHO, thus promoting the selective production of formate. And the Cu2O (100) crystal facet had higher formate generation activity than the (111) crystal facet. (3) Double element doping. All of the above are single element doping. Different dopant atoms play different roles. Doping two elements at the same time can further optimize the reaction, and the synergistic effect between dopant atoms will provide higher reactivity. Li et al. [163] prepared an in situ double-doped electrocatalyst(Ag,S-Cu2O/Cu) for the catalytic reduction of CO2 to CH3OH. As shown in Fig. 19(a), its FE could be as high as 67.4%. The interaction of S, Ag and Cu2O enhanced the selectivity and current density for the conversion of CO2 to CH3OH. It was shown that the anion S could modulate the electronic structure of Cu2O, while the cation Ag had an inhibitory effect on the HER (Fig. 19(b)-(c)). The double doping of anions and cations improves the activity and selectivity of CO2 to methanol, and the double-atom doping provides a new idea for the study of efficient CO2 reduction catalysts. Based on the above research applications of defect construction in the Cu2O catalytic CO2RR, we find that the construction defects directly affect the energy band structure and electronic structure of Cu2O. This can effectively improve the current density and electrocatalytic activity. Vacancies and dopant atoms are usually important to the reaction as catalyst active sites, affecting the ability to absorb and desorb key species. The type of doping elements affects the selectivity of CO2 reduction products, and the doped atoms can be selected according to the production requirements. In general, the construction of defects is not a less effective strategy to improve the catalyst performance. However, there are fewer studies for vacancy and two-element doping, which provide research directions for future development of Cu2O catalysts. 4.3 Current status of electrocatalytic CO2 to C3 products on Cu2O The formation of C2 products, such as C2H4 and C2H5OH, has been successfully achieved in Cu2O electrocatalyzed CO2RR, and the modified catalysts have shown promising performance. At the same time, the formation of a more commercially viable C2+ product is more desirable and more challenging. The diversity of protonation sites of the C1 and C2 intermediates limits the generation of C3 and allows for a more complex reaction pathway. However, in previous studies, the generation of C3 products (e.g., n-propanol [18]) was achieved over Cu2O-based catalysts. As in the previous C2 generation, higher CO coverage and longer residence time remain favourable conditions for the formation of the second C-C bond. Overall, for the generation of C3 products, we can explore the reaction paths and mechanisms, which can provide reference for the rational design of our catalysts. Chang et al. [164] demonstrated that the Cu0-Cu+ mixing region on the oxygen-depleted Cu2O (110) surface realizes the coupling of H2CCO to CO. DFT calculations showed that specific C1/C2 intermediates could be stabilized by adjusting the valence state of Cu2O (110), and that properly hydrogenated C2 intermediates were more favourable for the generation of C3, that is, H2CCO species. On this catalyst this coupling reaction had a lower activation energy and was thermodynamically more favourable. This result also demonstrated the critical role of Cu0-Cu+ synergy in the reaction. However, Cu+ substances are easily reduced to metallic Cu at high current densities, and the formation and stabilization of the Cu0-Cu+ interface is important. Du et al. [165] showed that trace halide ion adsorption could slow down the kinetics of Cu+ reduction to Cu0, allowing in situ control of the formation and stabilization of the Cu0-Cu+ interface. The abundant Cu0-Cu+ interface facilitated the C-C coupling reaction and inhibited the HER. The catalyst had a 75.7% FE (0.98 V vs RHE) for C2 and C2+ products, providing us with a simple strategy to prepare high performance catalysts. Wu et al. [166] demonstrated that Cu2O nanocubes under CO atmosphere produced Cu2O-Cu hybrid catalysts rich in nanocrystalline boundaries by thermal reduction. The abundant nanocrystalline boundary structure allowed the Cu0-Cu+ interface to be preserved at high current densities and high polarization states. It increased the adsorption density of *CO and facilitated the C-C coupling reaction, resulting in high C2+ product selectivity. Zhang et al. [167] who prepared a series of hollow Cu2O nanoreactors with different cavity sizes to stabilize Cu+ species and regulate the Cu+/Cu0 ratio. The concentration of intermediates could also be adjusted to facilitate subsequent reactions. The FE of the C2+ product on the optimally sized hollow Cu2O reactor was as high as 70.1%. The cavity size has a close relationship with the Cu+/Cu0 ratio, *CO coverage, and reaction selectivity, and this study provides a reference for catalyst design. The above studies illustrate the important role of Cu0-Cu+ mixed valence in electrocatalytic CO2RR, but researchers hold different insights into the reasons for the high selectivity of the C2+ product. Lei et al. [168] prepared copper-based electrodes with different initial oxidation states (Cu/Cu2O/CuO and Cu/Cu(OH)2) to investigate the source of the excellent selectivity of C2+. Their results concluded that the metal Cu was the active species in the reaction and that the type of catalyst starting oxidation state did not affect the selectivity results. In addition, they pre-reduced both electrodes to ensure that only Cu0 species were present in the CO2RR process, and the results showed that the pre-reduced electrodes were even slightly more selective, suggesting a key role for Cu0 species. And at the same time, the authors found that the crystal fragmentation of Cu-based electrodes to form small Cu grains during the reduction process, the formation of a large number of grain boundaries and high-index facets were also the key reasons for the high C2+ selectivity. In conclusion, the authors provide a new insight into the structural and chemical states in the electrocatalytic CO2RR of Cu-based catalysts, showing the key roles of the active substance Cu0, grain boundaries, and high-index facets. It also provides a direction for us to focus our future work. In addition to the active components, a large reaction area, good CO2 adsorption capacity and mass transfer efficiency are also critical for the reaction. We can provide better reaction environments by constructing complexes or morphological modifications, for example, and we can also stabilize the active components in this way. Zhi et al. [169] prepared Cu/Cu2O@NG catalysts with N-doped graphene (NG) having large surface area and excellent electrical conductivity. Cu/Cu2O could be uniformly dispersed on NG, providing more active sites. Due to the good mass transfer rate and abundant active sites, the catalyst exhibited better C2+ product generation. Liu et al. [170] prepared Cu2O-2D metal-organic framework catalysts (Cu2O/Cu-BDC) with abundant heterogeneous interfaces. Among them, the 2D Cu MOFs material could stabilize the active substance Cu+ and increase the stability of the catalyst. The heterogeneous interface, however, optimized the adsorption behaviour of the reaction intermediates and stabilized the *CHO/*COH intermediates, thereby facilitating the C-C coupling reaction. That is, for the generation of C3 products, a stable active component Cu0-Cu+, a good reaction environment, and an appropriate degree of protonation of C1/C2 intermediates are crucial. In addition, the high energy barrier and slow kinetics of C3 generation are still the difficulties we need to overcome. We can conduct more research to overcome these challenges based on the above results. 4.4 Mechanistic study of Cu2O-based electrocatalysts Based on the above 4.2 study, Cu2O-based electrocatalysis has a good C2 generation capability, which is limited by the complex generation path and high kinetic barrier for C-C coupling. The most studied mode of C-C coupling is the dimerization of CO, but in fact, the direct dimerization of *CO is slow and has a high reaction potential, whereas the first hydrogenation of *CO to form *CHO and the subsequent reaction with the other hydrogenation product *CHxO is kinetically more favourable [132]. Ren et al. [24] showed that CO2RR involves both direct dimerization of *CO to produce OCCO and first hydrogenation-then coupling to produce C2HxO2. It suggests that the coupling of the properly hydrogenated intermediate *CHxO is kinetically more favourable. It is also argued that for the generation of C2H4/C2H5OH, *CH2CHO is an important common reaction intermediate, and that whether *CH2CHO is hydrogenated to *C2H4 or *CH2CHOH is critical. Yao et al. [125] showed that the adsorption of CO and COH by low-coordinated Cu atoms generated of Cu2O increases with the lesser number of atomic coordination. And for their study, the CO-COH coupling barrier decreases with decreasing coordination number, which is more favourable than the CO-CO coupling mode. They also indicated that in addition to the important influence of the C-C coupling mode, pH also has an important effect on the reaction, with alkaline environments favouring the production of C2H4 and C2H5OH. Overall, for the generation of C2 products, a high coverage of *CO is a prerequisite, and the manner of *C-C coupling determines the kinetic fastness. More current studies have proposed that *CO is kinetically more favourable when coupled after proper hydrogenation. We should continue to explore the reaction mechanism to deepen our understanding and clarify the key intermediate *CHxO and the rate-limiting step. At the same time, we need to conduct a deeper study of the pH effect to promote the selective generation of C3 products. In summary, for the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 by Cu2O, the most studied strategies for constructing efficient catalysts are mainly morphological modulation, metal deposition and defect construction. Grain boundaries, defects, active sites, and the introduction of a second component all have an important influence on the improvement of C2 product selectivity, which is mainly achieved by stabilizing the active substance, or changing the adsorption behaviour of the intermediate, or affecting the kinetics of the reaction. The selectivity of some specific products can be improved by some modification strategies. For example, (1) Catalysts with a core-shell structure can increase the generation of C2 products by stabilizing the active species Cu+, and increasing the likelihood of C-C coupling. (2) The crystallographic dependence effect causes a difference in the ease of response. High-index facets promote C-C coupling reactions due to the abundance of grain boundaries and defects; (111) facets favour the production of alcohols; and (332) facets favour the production of C2H4; In addition, charge transfer between the anisotropic faces of the crystal affects the kinetics of the reaction and enhances the FE of C2. (3) The introduction of the second component acts as an important active site and synergizes with Cu2O to promote the selective generation of C2. Ag and Au have better CO generation capacity, and the increased CO coverage favours the generation of C2, which has high selectivity for C2H4 and C2H5OH, and the appropriate composite ratio influences the selectivity of C2H4/C2H5OH; B indirectly improves the stability of Cu+ reactive species by inhibiting lattice oxygen in Cu2O, while optimizing the adsorption behaviour of *CO and enhancing the selectivity of C2H4. In addition to this, it has been shown that carbon coatings can stabilize Cu+ species in copper oxides, promote C-C coupling reactions. And it can modulate the adsorption behaviour of *HOCCH, prompting the selective generation of C2H5OH with high FE and current density [171]. And the alkaline environment in the vicinity of the electrode also favours the generation of C2 products [24,125]. In conclusion, for electrocatalytic CO2RR, in addition to the C1 products, the Cu2O-based catalysts also showed good C2 generation ability. The product distribution was mainly concentrated on CO, C2H4, C2H5OH and a small amount of n-propanol, and the FE is basically more than 75%, with some catalysts having a slightly lower effect of more than 50%. The modified Cu2O catalysts have enhanced C2 generation ability. For other CO2 reduction electrocatalysts, Ren et al. [172] reviewed the electrocatalysts used for CO2RR in recent years. Most of the studies focused on metal electrodes such as Cu, Au, Re, Co, etc., and did not show excellent C2 product generation, except for Cu-based catalysts that showed some C2 product generation, with the products being mainly CO, formate, and CH4. In addition, there are several reviews based on electrocatalytic CO2RR (graphite carbon nitride-based materials [173], metal-organic skeleton materials [174], and mesh materials [175]), which have shown better C1 generation. Thus, in short, copper-based catalysts, including Cu2O-based materials, with their excellent C2 generation capability make the materials superior and show a great potential that deserves a lot of research. 5 Research status of Cu2O photo-electrocatalytic CO2 reduction 5.1 Introduction to photo-electrocatalysis Photo-electrochemical (PEC) CO2 reduction combines the advantages of photocatalysis and electrocatalysis, it has unique advantages over single photocatalysis and electrocatalysis [176]: firstly, from the photocatalytic point of view, the presence of an external voltage promotes the effective separation of photo-generated electrons and holes and reduces the occurrence of photo-corrosion; Secondly, from an electrocatalytic point of view, solar energy provides a large charge, significantly reducing the consumption of electrical energy; Thirdly, under the synergistic effect of light-electricity, CO2RR has lower activation energy and easier reaction; Finally, PEC usually separate the cathode and anode, avoiding the mixing of CO2 reduction products and anode oxidation products. For photo-electrocatalytic reactions, the photoelectrode is usually a semiconductor material. It is immersed in an electrolyte solution and excited by light to produce photogenerated electrons and holes. Subsequently, electron-hole separation and transport are further facilitated by an applied voltage. CO2RR is carried out at the cathode surface and oxidation of water at the anode. Cu2O has a good development prospect as an excellent photoelectrode material. However, it still inevitably suffers from low stability. Photo-corrosion degrades its catalytic properties. Wang et al. [177] have investigated the photo-corrosion behaviour of Cu2O nanowire thin film catalysts during CO2RR. The results showed that the slow kinetics of CO2RR on the catalyst caused the accumulation of electrons, which was the main cause of photo-corrosion. This is manifested in the collapse of the catalyst structure, the weakening of the photo-responsiveness, and the reduction of the charge transfer capacity. By studying the photo-corrosion mechanism, we can promote the utilization of charge transport on Cu2O by rational means (e.g., constructing protective layers, introducing dopant atoms, and other strategies), and design high catalytic activity sites to develop Cu2O-based photo-electrocatalysts with higher activity and stability. 5.2 Strategies for building efficient Cu2O-based photo-electrocatalysts 5.2.1 Building a protective layer Faced with the problem that Cu2O is susceptible to photo-corrosion, a commonly used protection is the addition of corrosion-resistant layers, including MOF materials, carbon layers, and metal oxides which exhibit enhanced catalytic properties. Galante et al. [178] demonstrated that Cu2O catalysts with aminopolysiloxane protective layer exhibited enhanced photostability. It could selectively generate formate at low potentials with 61% FE. Lee et al. [179] prepared Cu2O nanowire catalysts with a Cu+ doped TiO2 overlayer, which showed enhanced photo-electrocatalytic properties and promoted the selective generation of CH3OH. However, there is no standard for the design of parameters such as deposition/cover layer thickness and temperature, and the study of the influencing mechanism is crucial for the improvement of catalytic performance. In this regard, Akbar et al. [180] investigated the role of TiO2 protective layers with different deposition temperatures and thicknesses on the photo-electrocatalytic performance of Cu2O. It showed that the TiO2 deposition thickness affected carrier transport, while the deposition temperature influenced its stability and conductivity. The results showed that the TiO2 coating with 2 nm thickness had the best effect on Cu2O at 150 °C. Subsequently, Akbar et al. indicated that Cu2O often occured as a composite catalyst, the presence of different protective layers caused a change in the active site and affected the selectivity of the reaction. The influencing factors for pure Cu2O photo-electrocatalyzed CO2RR are not clear. Therefore, Akbar et al. [181] had also investigated the structure and electrolyte composition of Cu2O. It was shown that Cu2O film thickness, cations in the electrolyte, and local pH affect the amount of the surface active substance Cu+, and that sustained Cu+ facilitates the formation of C2(CH3COOH) products, which is the key to improving selectivity. This work serves as a reference for us to carry out subsequent studies, and the development of new catalytic systems should fully consider all possible influencing factors. 5.2.2 Construct heterojunctions Heterojunction, as an important means to enhance the photocatalytic performance, also shows good promise in the enhancement of Cu2O photo-electrocatalytic performance. Aranda-Aguirre et al. [33] prepared Cu2O-Bi2Se3 heterojunction catalysts on fluorine-doped tin oxide substrates. The unique electronic properties of the topological insulator Bi2Se3 could enhance photoexcitation and electron transport on the Cu2O surface, making it an excellent catalyst for CH3OH generation. The authors also point out that pH is an important influence on the selectivity of photo-electrocatalytic CO2 reduction products. Zoli et al. [182] prepared a Cu2O-SnO2 composite catalyst and demonstrated that the presence of the n-type semiconductor SnO2 protects the Cu+ active material from photo-corrosion. The formation of p-n junctions promoted the transfer of photo-generated electrons and avoided photo-corrosion in order to obtain catalysts with the active substance Cu+ as the main copper oxidation state. In addition to this, it had also been shown that the presence of Sn acted as an influence on the size of Cu2O particles, giving them a relatively narrow size distribution. This will affect the formation of active sites and the adsorption behaviour of the reaction intermediates. Otgonbayar et al. [183] prepared a ternary composite catalytic material of Ti3C2/Cu2O/Fe3O4. Among them, 2D MXene with large specific surface area provided abundant reactive sites. And it had better carrier transport ability and reactivity than carbon materials due to the abundance of metal sites and electrical conductivity. The Cu-Fe metal oxides, as excellent CO2 reduction catalysts, could form heterogeneous structures with it, which further promoted the separation and utilization of photo-generated electrons-holes. The main products of this composite catalyst were CH3OH and C2H5OH, which showed sufficient stability even after one month. 5.2.3 Elemental doping Protective layers and heterojunctions mainly improve the photo-corrosion behaviour of catalysts and enhance the utilization of photo-generated electrons, thus enhancing the reactivity. And elemental doping, as a commonly used modification, directly affects the electronic structure of the surrounding atoms and the composition of the catalyst. Changes in the surface state affect the adsorption behaviour of the reaction intermediates, which can regulate the reaction selectivity more efficiently. Guo et al. [184] reported a Ga-doped Cu2O catalyst with good C2+ product (ethanol and propanol) generation. Ga doping promoted light absorption and electron-hole separation of the catalyst. Meanwhile the improved electronic structure and the formation of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface promoted the activated adsorption of CO2 and the occurrence of C-C coupling. 5.2.4 Functional modification Jia et al. [185] argued that the designed Cu2O-based photo-electrocatalytic material should satisfy each factor of the reaction process one by one, and proposed an efficient multifaceted composite catalytic material, including a hole-transporting layer (to collect holes and improve the stability of the catalyst), a Cu2O photonic crystal structure (to improve the light absorption and provide a microenvironment for the reaction), and a polypyrrole layer (to act as an electron-transferring agent and to activate the CO2 molecule). Through the synergistic action of the components, the catalyst had a CO yield of up to 46.17 mmol·h-1. This synergistic effect of multicomponent functional modifications also provides a rational scheme for carrying out catalyst design. Overall, catalyst nanostructures, protective layers, heterojunctions and doping strategies are all effective means to improve the performance of Cu2O photo-electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. We can introduce co-catalysts with efficient CO reduction activity under the premise of ensuring that the catalysts have good light absorption and effective utilization of photogenerated electrons-holes. This further reduces the reaction potential barrier and modulates the selectivity of the catalyst. That is to say, through the synergistic effect between the components, the catalyst has both efficient light utilization and more catalytic active sites. The above section of this paper summarizes the current status of Cu2O-based photo-/electrocatalysts for CO2RR applications, which exhibit improved activity and selectivity. And some researchers have shown that the Cu2O-based catalysts still have high stability after multiple reuses, but most of them are stable within 100 h. The catalysts are still affected by photo-corrosion and structural reorganization, which cause the problem of reductive oxidative inactivation of the active substances. In addition to valence effects, they may also be affected by changes in surface structure, e.g., changes in porosity, crystal facts, interfacial energies, etc., during the reaction process. The reconfiguration behaviour of a catalyst will always have a positive or negative effect over the course of a long reaction. For photocatalytic reactions, the timely transfer and utilization of photogenerated electrons is the key to improving catalytic activity and avoiding photo-corrosion, which largely maintains the stability of the catalyst. For electrocatalytic reactions, the level of the potential and the size of the catalyst affect the occurrence of surface remodeling. Cu2O-based catalysts usually undergo a complex structural reconstruction process during the electroreduction process, and may be reduced to metallic copper, presenting copper catalytic activity, or have altered crystal facts, etc. We can make an in-depth study of the reconfiguration effect, which is induced to stabilize the active substance or change it in a favourable direction. Jiang et al. [186] proposed a concept of Cu2O superparticles. During the structural remodeling process, the internal structural units of the particle generate a large number of copper grain boundaries, and the structural units of the outer shell segregate to form nanogap structures that restrict OH species to maintain an alkaline environment. This particular superstructure achieves high C2 product selectivity, and this study demonstrates the importance of catalyst precursor structure studies for the design of active center species. 6 Development trend of Cu2O-based catalytic CO2RR 6.1 Research directions of new catalysts based on Cu2O The above section of this paper summarize the existing modification strategies commonly used on Cu2O catalysts, all of which have achieved remarkable results. Currently, there are many new catalysts applied in CO2RR. They have higher catalytic activity and selectivity. But for Cu2O-based catalysts, they have not received much attention. Fig. 20 shows the possible future directions of catalysts for CO2RR, mainly including ADCs, dual doping catalysts, FLPs and tandem catalysts. A brief description will be given below. 6.1.1 Single-atom catalysts Metal catalysts, which are widely studied, have good prospects for application in CO2RR. However, it also has certain problems, most notably, easy aggregation deactivation and low atom utilization efficiency [187]. As a result, single-atom catalysts (SACs) with atomically dispersed metal centers have attracted attention. Qiao [187] first proposed the concept of SACs in 2011. It has also been more explored by researchers since then and has developed rapidly. SACs can effectively solve the disadvantages of metal catalysts that tend to aggregate and deactivate [188]. The unique advantage of atomically dispersed metal centers allows SACs to have high atom utilization efficiency and catalytic activity. Among them, the loaded single-atom metal catalysts not only promote the charge transfer but also utilize the synergistic effect of metal atoms with the carrier, which further improves the performance of the reaction [189]. Enhancing the strong interaction between the loaded metal and the carrier is significant in improving the reactivity and selectivity. Based on the current studies of SACs in Cu2O-catalyzed CO2RR, the positive role of single-atom modifiers in stabilizing the active species Cu+ has been confirmed. As shown in Fig. 21(a)-(b), the single-atom Sn indirectly promoted the adsorption of intermediate *CO and enhanced CO production by stabilizing Cu+ species, due to the enhanced charge transfer between Sn-O-Cu [190]; Gd single-atom doping not only stabilized the Cu+ species but also induced tensile strain, which could reduce the potential barrier of the C-C coupling reaction and thus promoted the formation of C2+ products, due to the positive effect of the large ionic radius and electronic structure of the lanthanide metal Gd on the reaction (Fig. 21(c)) [191]. In addition, Le et al. showed that plasma-induced direct dissociation of CO2 had a relatively low potential barrier and further investigated the catalytic performance of the composite system of plasma and Cu2O in the presence of oxygen vacancies, which showed superior performance [111,192]. The results of this study demonstrate the positive synergistic effect of plasma-excited high-energy electrons and defects in promoting CO2 reduction. SACs have relatively higher atomic utilization rates and catalytic activity compared to bulk metals. However, SACs can also suffer from particle agglomeration, low metal loading effects and difficult scale-up implementation in the context of CO2RR. New preparation methods need to be developed to improve its stability and activity and further optimize the performance. 6.1.2 Double-atom catalysts Double-atom catalysts (DACs) are atomic dimers loaded on a carrier. Compared to single-atom catalysts, DACs have dual active sites, and they can further complete more complex catalyst reactions while maintaining high atomic utilization. Loaded metal DACs can effectively modulate the electronic structure of surrounding atoms because of interatomic interactions [193]. And they can increase the possible pathways and activity of the reactions by affecting the formation of reaction intermediates [194], providing multi-locus adsorption and atomic bond breaking that cannot be achieved with single-atom catalysts, and have very good prospects for development. The commonly used catalyst substrates are mainly metal oxides, carbon materials, and MOFs materials. In addition, DACs are divided into homonuclear and heteronuclear structures. Among them, DACs with different elemental species exhibit better catalytic activity [195,196]. Because different metals have stronger synergistic effects with each other and provide different active sites and roles in the reaction. DACs have now been used for CO2RR, and the synergy between atoms and more active sites further enhances the activity and selectivity of CO2RR [197]. A brief description of recent DACs for CO2RR is given below. I Homonuclear structure of DACs: Jiao et al. [198] proposed an "atom pair catalyst", i.e., adjacent Cu atom catalysts with Cu1 0-Cu1 x+ structure for CO2 and H2O adsorption, respectively. It was shown that the unique adsorption structure could effectively reduce the activation energy of CO2 and exhibited better CO generation activity, selectivity and high stability at low potentials. Ni et al. [199] synthesized a catalyst with a double - single Co atom for the CO2 reaction to produce syngas ( Fig. 22(a)). They indicated that single Co sites were used for CO2RR, while double Co atomic sites were used for HER, and the synergistic effect of double single Co sites resulted in a catalyst with high activity. This dual single-atom catalyst also provides us with a reliable strategy for designing efficient catalysts. As shown in Fig. 22(b), Wang et al. [200] showed that the dual Fe atomic sites had better CO generation performance than single-atom Fe, attributed to the synergistic interaction (orbital coupling) between the dual Fe atomic sites, which improved the adsorption behaviour of *CO. And the catalyst had high CO generation FE and enhanced stability. Zhao et al. [201] also showed that the synergistic interaction between dual Fe atomic sites could enhance the CO2 activation and CO resolution of the catalysts with much higher CO generation capacity than single Fe atom catalysts. In addition, Liang et al. [202] prepared diatomic Ni catalysts and showed that the synergistic interaction between Ni-Ni sites could reduce the reaction free energy and promoted the formation of *COOH, resulting in a catalyst with high CO generation capacity (Fig. 22(c)). The above study responds to the positive effects of the synergistic interactions between the two atoms on the reaction, including the activation of CO2, the adsorption behaviour of intermediates, and the reaction potential, while integrating the advantages of the single-atom system to further improve the performance of the catalyst. II Heteronuclear structure of DACs: Cheng et al. [203] showed that Ni/Cu diatomic catalysts had an enhanced electron transport capacity and *COOH adsorption strength, as well as a low reaction potential barrier, thus promoting efficient CO production. Subsequently, Li et al. [204] developed an adjacent Cu-Cu/Cu-Ni diatomic catalyst and showed that the synergistic interaction between Cu-Cu facilitated the C-C coupling reaction to reduce CO to C2+ products with up to 91% FE ( Fig. 23(a)). This is also the inherent ability of Cu catalysts to generate C2. The Cu-Ni site, on the other hand, generated CH4 due to excessive CO adsorption. This study provides an idea to rationalize the reaction selectivity. Hu et al. [205] proposed a transition metal-main group metal diatomic catalyst (Fig. 23(b)), where the main group metal was chosen as the HER inert metal to inhibit the side reaction and the transition metal was used as the active site for CO2RR. It showed that the Cu-In catalyst had a FE of 96% for CO generation. The In atoms around the active site Cu can improve the adsorption behaviour of * COOH on Cu site and further promotes CO production. Wu et al. [206] successfully prepared Fe-Mn diatomic catalysts, and the presence of Mn enhanced the catalytic ability of Fe atoms. The study confirmed that the synergistic effect of the diatoms promoted the activated adsorption of CO2 as well as the desorption of *CO (Fig. 23(c)). In addition, as shown in Fig. 23(d), Liu et al. [207] showed that the Cu-Sn diatomic catalyst also exhibited enhanced CO2 activation, with the FE of CO for this catalyst being as high as 99.1%, much higher than that of the Cu/Sn monoatomic catalyst. In general, most of the current diatomic catalysts exhibit good CO selectivity and are less studied for other products. However, compared with single-atom catalysts, the performance improvement is obvious and has good potential for development. Cu2O is an excellent metal oxide carrier, and we believe that constructing diatomic metal catalysts on its surface can significantly improve its deficiencies and enhance the activity and product selectivity of the catalyst. 6.1.3 Three-atom catalysts Three-atom catalysts (TACs) seem to be promising catalysts at the atomic dispersion level. They further improve the coordination environment of metal atoms and provide more active sites [208]. However, their preparation is more complicated compared to SACs and DACs. This is because it is difficult to precisely control the atomic number during the synthesis process. In addition, the low coordination triatom has a high surface energy, which makes it less stable in the catalytic process. In short, the difficulty of preparation and the aggregation in the catalytic process limit the development of TACs. Based on this, the development and application of triatomic catalysts for substrate requirements is necessary important. At present, the application of TACs catalysts for CO2RR reduction is still relatively small and needs our vigorous development research. Current research on triatomic catalysts for CO2RR has focused on carbon-based materials, which are commonly used as catalyst substrates and have a special pore size structure that can better stabilize the triatomic configuration. Zha et al. [209] studied the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction performance of a transition metal triatomic system (Fe, Co, Ni and Cu) on C2N by DFT. The results showed that these catalysts were all more selective than HER for CO2RR and could complete the reaction at a lower overpotential. And the type of transition metal had an important influence on the reaction selectivity. The Cu triatomic catalysts had better CO and HCOOH selectivity, while Co3 was more favourable for the formation of CH3OH and CH4 compared to other transition metals. This study provides guidance for the rational development of polyatomic catalysts, including the rational selection of catalyst substrates and atomic species. Subsequently, Zhou et al. [210] investigated the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction performance of a transition metal triatomic system (Fe, Co, and Cu) on a graphene substrate by DFT. And structural analysis showed that the triatomic metals had high cohesion and large binding energies, indicating that graphene was an excellent substrate that ensures stability during the reaction. The electronic structure analysis showed a large amount of charge transfer between the metal atoms and the C atoms of graphene, and the synergistic interaction between the atoms promoted the activated adsorption of CO2 ( Fig. 24). Among them, the copper atom favoured the production of CH4, while the iron atom promoted the production of CH3OH, and the HER was limited with increasing potential. Han et al. [211], on the other hand, investigated triatomic catalysts composed of bimetals, which showed that the triatomic catalysts could effectively achieve activated CO2 adsorption and the Fe2Ir structure could also effectively inhibit the occurrence of HER with good CO2 reduction performance. Overall, current research on triatomic catalysts applied to CO2RR is still relatively scarce and mainly focused on theory, with experimental studies limited by difficulties in preparation. But some successful preparation methods have also been developed. Atomic layer deposition, which allows precise control of the deposition behaviour of metal atoms, has been successfully used for the preparation of atomically loaded metals [212]. In addition, catalysts with excellent pore structure are a good substrate for triatomic catalysts. We can optimize the pore structure of Cu2O by heat treatment or chemical hydrolysis so that it can stabilize the triatomic catalysts better. Moreover, the construction of vacancy defects on the surface of Cu2O is relatively easy, based on the defect anchoring strategy, which is also advantageous for the immobilization of other metal atoms. Overall, we believe that Cu2O-based triatomic catalysts can be realized in CO2RR in the future and show good catalytic performance. 6.1.4 Fully exposed catalyst-larger clusters In addition to the three atom-dispersed catalysts mentioned above, cluster catalysts have also been developed rapidly. Cluster catalysts can accommodate dozens or even tens of metal atoms while maintaining a smaller size. Compared to single-atom catalysts, they still offer excellent atom utilization and provide more active sites at the same time [213]. Metal clusters have a more complex atomic coordination environment. For the complex CO2RR, the unsaturated metal coordination and unique electronic structures of clusters are more favourable to improving the activity and selectivity of the reaction [214,215]. And the diverse active sites and interatomic synergies make the formation of complex reaction intermediates possible. Loaded metal cluster catalysts have been studied in CO2RR, such as Pt8/In2O3 [216], Nin/YSZ(111) [217], and Ni/γ-Al2O3 [218], all of which show enhanced catalyst performance. And they indicate that the metal-oxide interface is the active site. The strong interaction of metal clusters with the carrier enhances the charge transfer and facilitates the active adsorption of CO2. For cluster catalysts, there is a relatively special class of catalysts, namely, fully exposed cluster catalysts (FECCs). This type of catalyst is intermediate between SACs and nanoparticles (NPs), and all its metal atoms can be used as reactive sites for adsorption, conversion and desorption of molecules. Compared to the common large cluster catalysts, the structures are relatively dispersed and mostly layered, which have stronger interactions with the carrier surface [219]. For the preparation of FECCs, based on the current study, we can capture metal atoms by introducing surface defects, and then further regulate the distribution of atomic and electronic structures by doping with a second element to promote their dispersion and stabilization on the substrate surface [220]. Such catalysts usually exhibit high catalytic activity and stability and have been extensively studied in recent years for a variety of catalytic reactions. For example, as shown in Fig. 25(a), Liu et al. [221] designed a fully exposed Cu7 cluster catalyst for the reduction of CO, which can generate formaldehyde with high selectivity and activity (Fig. 25(b)). The authors showed that this was due to the unique electronically mixed valence state of the Cu7 cluster (neutral in the middle with a cationic state at the edges) as well as synergistic effects that alter the adsorption behaviour of the intermediates. Hao et al. [222] investigated the application of fully exposed Ni cluster catalyst in CO2RR. The catalysts had a high FE for CO formation (up to 99%), partial current density and durability. The authors showed that the synergistic effect of multiple Ni atoms accelerated the reaction kinetics, and also suggested that S-atom doping had a positive effect on the charge distribution at Ni sites, providing a reference for the regulation of fully exposed catalysts. Dong et al. [223], on the other hand, investigated the ability of fully exposed Pd cluster catalysts to produce hydrogen from nitrogen heterocycles. They compared the dehydrogenation ability of single-atom, sub-nanoclusters and nanoparticles. And the results showed that fully exposed Pd clusters could activate the reactants better and promote the desorption of the products, but the activity of single-atom Pd was almost 0. The results of this study demonstrated that fully exposed metal clusters could significantly enhance the catalytic properties and atomic utilization of metals, and their synergistic effects greatly facilitated the reactions. In addition, FECCs is also widely used for alkane dehydrogenation (Fig. 25(c)). Its special fully exposed active site has a good C-H activation capacity, while the electron-rich surface facilitates the timely desorption of H2 to improve the durability of the catalyst [220]. The excellent performance of FECC in HER and alkane dehydrogenation further demonstrates the potential capability of this structured catalyst in terms of atom utilization, reactant activation, and long-term stability, which is worthy of more in-depth study in CO2RR. Currently for Cu2O, based on the above photo- /electrocatalytic modification studies, it can be seen that the catalyst activity can be effectively enhanced by loading the metal. However, for cluster catalysts, including FECCs, there has been no application in Cu2O-catalyzed CO2RR. Based on the excellent performance of FECCs, their use as a structural form of loaded metal for the metal-Cu2O system further improves the atom utilization and provides more active sites. The highly exposed atomic structure and low electron coordination environment of FECCs allow for efficient catalytic activity. The synergistic effect of polyatoms not only facilitates the activated adsorption of reactant molecules, but also promotes the desorption of products and prevents catalyst poisoning. Thus, it seems that for CO2RR, FECCs are a promising advanced catalyst to meet the requirements of activity and selectivity of the reaction. And similar to the preparation of triatomic catalysts, we can also prepare FECCs on Cu2O by atomic layer deposition methods or defect anchoring. In addition, a second element can be introduced to modulate its coordination environment and promote its dispersion and stabilization in the substrate. Based on the above study, perhaps we can realize the successful preparation and application of FFECs on Cu2O surface with defects. 6.1.5 Dual doping catalysts Vacancy/atom doping has already been mentioned as having a positive influence on the activity and selectivity of the reaction. Doping can change the surface electronic structure of the catalyst and act as an important active site to regulate the adsorption behaviour and reaction direction of intermediates on the catalyst. Among them, two-atom doping is an interesting approach, which further exploits the synergistic effect of two dopant atoms on the basis of single-atom doping while providing different effects on the reaction [224,225]. And the anions and cations with opposite charges can play a greater role in improving the catalyst performance. The current strategy of double doping has been effectively applied in reactions such as HER and oxygen reduction (ORR) [226–228], and we believe that this is also true for CO2RR. In recent years, research on double doping strategies for CO2 reduction catalysts has focused on non-metallic carbon materials. For example, N,S double-doped carbon-based catalysts, which had lower Gibbs free energy for the formation of *COOH compared to single N doping, exhibited high CO selectivity and durability ( Fig. 26(a)-(b))[229]. The N, P-doped carbon nanosheets exhibited high FE of CO and long-lasting stability at low overpotentials (Fig. 26(c)). The N acted as the active center of the reaction, while the addition of P not only improved the pore structure of the material but also enhanced the intrinsic activity of the doped N. That is, the synergistic effect of N,P was the main reason for the excellent properties of this material [230]. The B, P-doped graphene nitride catalyst had a strong ability to convert CO to C2H4 (Fig. 26(d)). Its suitable adsorption energy of CO and C2H4 promoted the C-C coupling reaction and the timely desorption of products, and B-P acted as the active center of the reaction instead of B-N, prompting the formation of C2H4 [231]. All the above works demonstrate the excellent performance of double doping and the positive effect of using the synergy between polyatoms on the performance enhancement of catalysts. For the Cu2O catalytic system, a typical application case of the double doping strategy is mentioned in the fourth part of the paper. Li et al. [163] proposed an Ag, S double-doped Cu2O/Cu catalyst. The authors started from three considerations: first, to improve the selective generation of product methanol, and second, it should serve to inhibit HER. In addition, the durability of the material should be improved. The results also demonstrated that the anion S promoted the production of CH3OH by regulating the electronic structure of the active center Cu, and the cation Ag could inhibit HER better. It could jointly promote the reduction performance of the material by enhancing the primary reaction and inhibiting the secondary reaction in different aspects. Such catalysts are efficient and stable and are of interest. However, it has not been extensively studied for Cu2O-based catalysts. This work also provides a reference for future research design of doped catalysts, which has good prospects for development. 6.1.6 Frustrated Lewis pairs catalyst In recent years, FLPs were found to have high translational properties in CO2RR [232–234]. The concept of FLPs was first introduced by Stephan in 2006 [235]. And subsequently it was found that FLPs have a better polarization and splitting effect on small molecules, facilitating their next reaction and transformation [236,237]. This is important for the CO2RR that can effectively solve the problem of high CO2 activation potential. The catalytic principle of FLPs is that Lewis acids (rich in unoccupied orbitals) and Lewis bases (rich in lone pair electrons) form active regions due to the presence of large spatial site resistance rather than direct bonding [233]. The bonding and antibonding orbitals of the CO2 molecule interact with the empty orbitals and lone pair electrons of the Lewis acid/base in the active region, respectively, thus promoting the activation and dissociation of CO2. Many successful cases of constructing FLPs on metal oxides, such as CeO2, TiO2, have been reported so far. For example, oxygen vacancies and their nearby hydroxyl groups can form FLPs that facilitate the CO2 reduction reaction [232,238,239]. It has also been suggested that the activity of catalysts can be enhanced by shortening the distance of Lewis acid base, which can adsorb and activate CO2 more efficiently [240]. Here are some typical cases. Ⅰ CeO2 system: The CeO2(110) surface is widely studied compared to the (100) and (111) surfaces because its abundant oxygen vacancies make the construction of FLPs easy. By introducing oxygen vacancies, the O2- atoms (Lewis bases) formed FLPs with Ce3+ atoms (Lewis acids) in their vicinity, and the C in the CO2 molecule bound to O2- while the O atoms interact with Ce3+, thus facilitating the activated adsorption of CO2. The activation of CO2 is a prerequisite for the effective reduction of CO2. As shown in Fig. 27(a), Zhang et al. [241] showed that FLPs on CeO2 have great potential to induce CO2-activated adsorption. Subsequently, Ban et al. [242] designed a catalyst with a double active center for the reaction of CO2 and CH4 to acetic acid. By introducing transition metal single atoms (SA) on the CeO2(110) face, the presence of SA promoted the formation of oxygen vacancies, thus constructing the FLP site, which is the SA-FLP double active site. This special structure allowed for simultaneous activation of CO2 (FLP site) and CH4 (SA site), avoiding competitive adsorption and activation of reactant molecules with high activity. This dual active center catalyst construction also provide good inspiration. In addition, Ni serves as an excellent catalyst for CO2 methanation, and some current studies have been conducted on the construction of FLPs on Ni-CeO2 system. Xie et al. [243] found that the metal Ni could promote the dissociation of H2, and the formed H atoms contributed to the formation of FLPs by attacking the surface Ce-O building to form oxygen vacancies (Lewis acids) and OH groups (Lewis bases). The catalyst exhibited good low-temperature CO2 methanation activity. While Barreau et al. [244] showed that CeO2 loaded Ni particles can form FLP sites (Ce-O), typical Lewis pairs (CLP, Ni-O) and Ni-Ce synergistic sites, giving the catalyst excellent CH4 generation activity and selectivity. II TiO2 system: TiO2 has been widely studied as a common catalyst for CO2 reduction. Jia et al. [232] prepared TiO2-x catalysts with FLPs, and again, the surface oxygen vacancies are Lewis acid sites and the OH groups were Lewis base sites (Fig. 27(b)). The catalyst had excellent CO yield in pure water (65.1 μmolg−1h−1) and without any co-catalyst or sacrificial agent. This yield was 19.1 times higher than that of the TiO2 catalyst without FLPs, with significant performance enhancement. III In2O3 system: For the In2O3 system, recent studies have confirmed the role of doping in optimizing Lewis acidity, and doping as a commonly used modification can significantly improve the performance of the catalyst. Dong et al. [245] showed by DFT that the homocrystalline substitution of Bi3+ for In3+ significantly improved the performance of photocatalytic CO2RR. The FLPs site of this catalyst is In-OH, and the substitution doping of Bi not only improved the Lewis acidity of this catalyst, but Bi3+ also acted as an active site for H2 decomposition and further promoted CO2 reduction. Yan et al. [246], on the other hand, developed a simple one-step solvothermal synthesis method that successfully achieved the homocrystalline substitution of Bi3+ for In3+, providing a stronger Bi3+-O2- FLPs for the reaction, resulting in a catalyst with enhanced inverse water-gas shift reaction activity and CH3OH production activity. In addition, the introduction of Bi3+ single atoms adjusted the energy band structure of the catalyst, enhanced the light absorption ability, and more recently promoted the photocatalytic ability. The above study fully illustrates the possibility of metal oxide catalysts with abundant surface defects to construct FLPs with high performance, and it also shows that the reaction performance can be further improved by introducing single-atom catalysts. In conclusion, the construction of FLPs on metal oxide systems to improve their CO2 reduction performance is very promising, also for Cu2O. However, for the time being, there are relatively few studies on the construction of FLPs on Cu2O. Wan et al. [247] synthesized a Cu2O nanocube catalyst with mixed oxidation state Cu(0, 1, 2) sites, OH groups and oxygen vacancies on the surface. The catalyst could accomplish the activated adsorption of CO2 and the cleavage of H2 under mild conditions. And by adjusting the surface structure of Cu2O with SFLP Cu(0, 1, 2)-OH, the reversal of Cu2O disproportionation reaction could be realized and the disadvantage of poor stability of Cu2O could be improved. Jin et al. [248] proposed a method to activate CO2 by constructing Lewis acid-base sites based on an in-plane heterogeneous structure strategy. It was found that the Lewis acid-base site at the Cu2O/Cu heterogeneous interface can promote the dual coordination of surface C and O, thus enhancing the CO2 adsorption activity. And this structure has high electron transfer efficiency, which also gives this material excellent dimethyl carbonate generation performance. This is also a new strategy for the construction of FLPs. These studies show very good prospects for the design of Cu2O-based CO2 reduction catalysts. 6.1.7 Tandem catalysts Based on tandem catalytic reactions in multi-enzyme catalytic systems, the advantages of tandem catalysts have been discovered for the production of complex chemicals [249,250]. An advantage of tandem catalysts is the absence of intermediate product separation and purification, but the high mass transfer efficiency required for the intermediates and the mass transfer efficiency between the active sites ensures that the next step of the reaction is carried out efficiently; Another advantage is reflected in the thermodynamics, where the consumption of intermediates in the latter part of the reaction indirectly promotes the occurrence of the first part of the reaction and drives the whole reaction. Current tandem catalysts have been designed for use in CO2RR systems [251–253]. For CO2RR, the tandem catalyst provides different active sites to segment the conversion of CO2 to CO and CO to other C1 and C2+ products. As an important intermediate of CO2RR, the generation and utilization of CO is of great significance to the CO2RR reaction. We know that copper-based catalysts are excellent C-C coupling catalysts, but they still have problems such as difficult CO2 activation, poor selectivity and low yield. The application of tandem catalysts will effectively achieve the selective generation of C2 high-value products and provide a new idea for the development of Cu2O-based catalysts. The current research on copper-based tandem catalysts mainly focuses on Cu metal and CuO and Cu2O, which are described in detail below. Ⅰ Metal Cu: Studies on metallic Cu have focused on the Ag-Cu system [254–256], presumably because Ag has better CO generation properties that exactly complement the Cu properties [84,85]. Chen et al. [255] constructed Ag-Cu tandem electrocatalysts and demonstrated that the addition of Ag effectively increased the activity of C2 product generation on Cu catalysts ( Fig. 28(a)), indicating that the generation of CO on Ag and the subsequent C-C coupling reaction on Cu are crucial for efficient C2 generation. Thereafter, Iyengar et al. [257] further investigated the crystal facet dependence on Ag-Cu catalyst for efficient C2H5OH generation. The results showed that the Cu(111) nano-octahedral structure had more active sites for C2H5OH generation and better C2H5OH selectivity compared to the Cu(100) nanocubes (Fig. 28(b)). Zhang et al. [258] prepared Cu -Ag catalysts with adjustable thickness of core-shell structure to achieve optimal catalytic performance by optimizing the silver shell thickness. It showed that a suitable thickness of catalyst could significantly enhance the binding strength of CO and charge transfer efficiency at the interface and had the largest number of active sites, thus improving the selectivity of C2 products. The above study applied structural modulation to tandem catalysts, which provided insight into the development of highly selective catalysts. The metal Au also has a good ability to generate CO, there are also studies for Au-Cu catalysts, which showed the same results. And it was shown that heterogeneously linked catalysts are the most ideal choice to fully exploit the synergistic effect of both catalysts [259]. In addition to Ag and Au metals, Zhang et al. [260] prepared a CuO/Ni single-atom catalyst with Ni-Cu catalytic sites in close proximity. The catalyst achieved efficient generation and rapid consumption of CO. This catalyst showed the high FE of C2 product and high selectivity for C2H4 and C2H5OH. For CO2RR, more metal-Cu tandem catalysts should be studied and applied in addition to the heavily studied Ag, Au. For example, Zn, Pd, etc., which have also been shown to favour CO production in previous studies, in series with Cu will also potentially promote C2 production. Ⅱ CuO: The performance of tandem catalysts is mainly limited by the influence of the production and transfer utilization of CO. In response to the problem that the two active sites are too far apart to affect the reaction efficiency, Zhang et al. [260] prepared a CuO/Ni single-atom catalyst such that the two active sites, Ni (CO2 to CO) and Cu (deep reduction of CO), are adjacent to each other (Fig. 28(c)). The catalyst improved the utilization of intermediate CO, exhibiting excellent FE of C2+ product (81.4%). This work provides a new idea and inspiration for the design of tandem catalysts. Ⅲ Cu2O: The above are the research applications of Cu and CuO, and there are also a few research applications for the Cu2O system. Niu et al. [262] showed that by putting Ag in series with Cu2O, the CO generated at the Ag active site further reacted on Cu2O. The high CO coverage on Cu2O reduced the reaction potential and facilitated the formation of multi-carbon products. Therefore, the reaction activity and the FE of the products could be further improved. In addition, Yang et al. [263] then revealed the interaction of the two components in the AgI-Cu2O catalyst during the electrochemical process. It showed that the iodine ions leached in situ from AgI could inhibit the complete reduction of CuO to obtain the active components Cu0 and Cu+, which further promoted the C-C coupling to generate C2 products. Also, the residual I species could modulate the electrons on Ag and promote the production of intermediate CO. This work provides a new approach to adjust the active component of the tandem catalyst. Xiong et al. [264] also showed the positive effect of tuning the active component and structural morphology on the catalyst performance. It optimized the content of Cu-N4/Cu2O by adjusting the geometry of the precursor MOFs to find the catalyst morphology with the best performance. The FE of CH4 on this catalyst was as high as 80% and selectivity as high as 60%, and showed that the key to the performance improvement was the high coverage of CO. In addition, as shown in Fig. 28(d), Ye et al. [261] proposed a phase engineering strategy to adjust the phase ratio of Cu@Cu2O core-shell structure catalysts to improve the FE of C2 products (up to 79%) by optimizing the structure of the catalyst. The authors showed that phase engineering can modulate the adsorption behaviour of both CO2 and intermediate *CO, enhancing adsorption and promoting the transfer and deep reduction of *CO, which is important for the reaction to produce C2 products. Overall, the main role of the tandem catalyst is to promote the formation, transfer and next reaction of important intermediates of CO as a way to improve the selective production of C2 products. And the studies also show that after two catalytic components are selected, we can further modify the catalysts, such as structural modulation, optimization of the tandem approach and proper selection of the co-catalysts, so as to further improve the catalyst performance. The current studies have shown that the construction of Cu2O-based tandem catalysts can significantly improve the C2 selectivity on Cu2O catalysts, which is a very promising strategy that we should continue to study in depth and innovate. 6.2 Application studies of other copper oxides This paper mainly summarizes the research on the modification of Cu2O in CO2RR. In addition, another oxide of copper, CuO, is also of great interest. For photocatalytic CO2RR, CuO has a relatively narrower band gap structure (1.2 eV∼1.9 eV) [265], which favours the absorption of visible light. As with Cu2O, the more negative conduction band structure is favourable for CO2 reduction. However, the valence band position is not favourable for H2O oxidation and does not directly provide the H+ required for the reaction. In addition, during the photocatalytic reaction, Cu+ and Cu2+ are continuously interconverted, and holes and electrons are consumed at different times, reducing the possibility of compounding and improving the utilization of photo-generated electrons [266]. But it is still plagued by photogenerated electron-hole complexes. For Cu2O, it is directly deactivated by its own redox reaction to produce copper and CuO. The holes and electrons are consumed at the same time, and the reverse reaction cannot occur to realize the generation of Cu2O. And for electrocatalytic CO2RR, CuO has a good electrocatalytic activity and selectivity for CH3OH products and can directly reduce CO2 to CH3OH [267]. Cu2O, on the other hand, can selectively generate C2H4 and C2H5OH, and its C2 generation ability is superior to that of CuO. The CuO/Cu2O is usually reduced during the CO2RR process. And copper is in a multivalent state coexisting, the synergistic effect between multivalent copper will further promote the activity of CO2RR. For CuO, the synergistic interaction of Cu+ and Cu2+ is crucial for its generation of C2 products. Based on the previous study, the higher catalytic activity of Cu+ species favours C-C coupling, which is an advantage of Cu2O. In addition, CuO has better electrical conductivity compared to Cu2O [268] and is often used as a cover layer for Cu2O materials to facilitate charge transfer. Overall, the good photocatalytic performance and CH3OH generation ability of CuO make it show great potential in CO2RR as well. Many strategies are also currently used to improve the catalytic ability of CuO in CO2RR, mainly in energy band modulation, photogenerated electron-hole utilization, and increasing the active sites. For example, Li et al. [267] improved the photocatalytic performance of CuO by N-doping. It effectively increased the photo-generated carrier concentration and electrochemical adsorption sites with an exponential increase in CH3OH yield. Razali et al. [269] loaded CuO on TiO2 nanotubes, which significantly improved the photogenerated electron-hole separation and thus enhanced the photocatalytic performance. Guo et al. [270], on the other hand, investigated the effect of the formation of atomically dispersed Sn catalysts on CuO defective surfaces on the reaction of CO2 to CH3OH. FE of the CH3OH up to 88.6%. The authors showed that it was because of the formation of localized Lewis acid base that exhibited high conductivity and activity. It was also because the metal-oxide synergy reduced the required potential barrier for the reaction. Pechenkin et al. [271] loaded CuO-In2O3 on halloysite nanotubes (HNT) and the presence of In2O3 enhanced the conversion of CO2. while the acid center of HNT completed the dehydration of CH3OH and further formed dimethyl ether. Ye et al. [272] investigated the effect of particle size and oxygen vacancies on the reaction activity and selectivity. Catalysts with smaller particle size and more oxygen vacancies improved the electrochemical reaction activity. Its enhanced activation of CO2 adsorption and selectivity of CO. Liu et al. [273] prepared ultrathin CuO nanosheets for the electrochemical reaction of CO2. And they spontaneously formed Cu/Cu2O heterostructures during the reaction. The catalyst showed a high FE of 84.5% for the reaction of CO2 to C2H4 due to the enhanced adsorption of *OCCOH intermediates by Cu+. This study confirms that the presence of nanosheet structure and heterojunction interface enhanced the charge transfer, resulting in a stable and selective catalyst. The above studies will provide important guidance for CuO-based catalysts for CO2RR. The current CuO-based catalyst research is mainly focused on the reaction of CO2 to CH3OH, and more efforts will be devoted to the generation of other products. Perhaps in the future we can focus on CuO at the same time to develop more and more efficient CuO catalysts. 6.3 Applications of machine learning CO2RR requires the intervention of efficient catalysts. As we mentioned in the introductory section, CO2 has a certain thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertia, and its reductive conversion is difficult. The presence of a catalyst can make the occurrence of CO2RR easier. Catalysts can optimize the reaction path, thereby reducing thermodynamic barriers and accelerating the kinetic speed of the reaction. In recent years, some progress has been made in high-throughput screening of CO2 reduction catalysts, such as DFT and ML computational methods [274]. Theoretical calculations can provide reference for the development of catalysts in the laboratory. We can explore the properties of the catalysts through DFT calculations, which will help us to prove the expected mechanism, selectivity and efficiency, provide detailed reaction mechanism and save our time and cost [275]. DFT will provide great convenience for the research of Cu2O-based catalysts in CO2RR. As shown in Sections 3.3 and 4.4 above (photo-/electrocatalytic mechanism), theoretical studies on CO2RR catalyzed by Cu2O-based catalysts have been carried out by DFT, which provide some insights. For photocatalysis, DFT calculations have shown that the key to the generation of C1 high-value products on Cu2O-based catalysts lies in the competition between the desorption and the protonation process of *CO, and the stronger *CO adsorption energy and favourable protonation processes promote the selective generation of CH4, CH3OH [43,96]. For electrocatalytic reactions, Cu2O exhibits good C2 generation capability [45,161]. Through DFT studies, we know that high coverage of *CO is a prerequisite for C-C coupling [144] and the high kinetic barrier of C-C coupling limits its development [132]. Studies of the C-C coupling mode have shown that it is kinetically more favourable when *CO is properly hydrogenated and then coupled [24,125]. Theoretical studies can help us identify key intermediates and rate-limiting steps to target catalyst optimization. However, DFT computation also has its inherent drawbacks [276]. For example, the time cost is high and the presence of errors between different exchange correlation functions. As a result, ML has received a lot of attention from researchers. By using ML in combination with DFT calculations to predict catalytic activity and selectivity of catalysts, the time consumption can be greatly reduced [277,278]. In recent years, ML has been used in photocatalytic [60]and electrocatalytic [279,280] reactions of CO2. It would be of great convenience if ML were used in the design of new high-performance copper oxide catalysts. This will help us to prove the mechanism, expected selectivity and efficiency, provide a detailed reaction mechanism and save our time and cost. In addition, there is an expectation that ML will continue to progress toward large databases and generalized algorithms. By extracting previous experimental and computational data and integrating them, the speed and accuracy of screening for various types of complex catalysts can be increased [281]. 7 Summary and outlook This paper analyses and discusses the current status of the application of Cu2O-based catalysts in the photo- /electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. Firstly, the advantages and disadvantages of Cu2O catalyst materials in CO2RR are briefly reviewed. Then strategies for the modification of Cu2O-based catalysts in CO2RR are systematically reviewed. These strategies include morphology and crystal facet modulation, construction of heterojunction/carbon matrix composites, metal deposition and defect construction to enhance stability, activity and selectivity of the Cu2O-based catalyst in CO2RR. Subsequently, future directions for the development of new Cu2O-based catalysts in CO2RR are proposed. Finally, new computational tool by combining ML with DFT is also proposed to predict new Cu2O-based catalyst in CO2RR. In general, the following conclusions are drawn. (1) As a CO2 reduction photocatalyst, Cu2O has the advantage of a suitable band gap width and a conduction band position favourable for CO2 reduction. However, it also has some shortcomings, the occurrence of Cu2O photo-generated electron-hole complex and photo-corrosion has a serious negative impact on the reaction. For this, current research on the performance of Cu2O photocatalytic CO2RR focuses on the capture and utilization of photo-generated electrons, which in turn mitigates the occurrence of its photo-corrosion. Firstly, the formation of crystal anisotropic surfaces, construction of heterojunction/carbon-based composites, and introduction of a second component can effectively achieve the separation of photo-generated electrons-hole for timely transfer to the surface for reaction. Secondly, compared with other heterostructures, the Z-type heterojunctions can efficiently utilize the optimal valence band/conducting band positions of both semiconductors for simultaneous CO2 reduction and H2O oxidation. This is something that cannot be done with Cu2O catalyst alone. In addition, the introduction of the second component, i.e. metal deposition and elemental doping, usually also acts as an important active site and indirectly affects the product species by influencing the adsorption behaviour of the reaction intermediates. In general, effective light absorption and electron-hole separation are prerequisites for photocatalytic reactions, while modulation of the adsorption behaviour of reaction intermediates is the key to improving the reaction selectivity. (2) In electrocatalytic CO2 reduction, copper-based catalysts have suitable CO binding energy and the ability to generate multicarbon products. Cu2O, as a common oxide of copper, has also attracted extensive research and exhibited good CO2 reduction performance. However, its development is also limited by several problems, such as higher CO2 activation potential, unsatisfactory product selectivity and the influence of HER. For electrocatalytic reactions, current research has focused on improving the FE of products and the inhibition of HER. Firstly, the catalysts with different morphologies have different structures and exposed crystal facets. The morphological and crystal facet modulation can improve the mass transfer efficiency and adsorption performance of the catalyst, which have favourable effects on the improvement of product FE. The available results show that the types of products on different crystal facets of Cu2O are also different. Secondly, metal deposition and elemental doping not only increase the current density, but also take full advantage of the synergistic effects between components to influence the intermediate product generation and conversion pathways, which improving the selectivity of the reaction. At the same time, the introduction of some elements has a certain inhibition effect on the HER. Finally, the construction of vacancy defects can regulate the electronic structure of the atoms around the vacancy and the forbidden band width of the catalyst, which facilitates the activated adsorption of CO2. It also influences the reaction potential and regulates the type of reaction products. Overall, the available studies show that Cu2O-based electrocatalysts have demonstrated a good C2 generation capability. Although the above modification strategies have possessed significant results for the optimization of Cu2O properties, the current practical application for Cu2O still has shortcomings and a lot of room for development. First, stability problem. With the increase of reaction time, Cu2O-based catalysts will still have valence and morphology changes, resulting in catalyst deactivation and low efficiency.
