Although some experimental studies have shown that the stability of Cu2O-based catalysts has been improved, and the catalysts still have a certain degree of activity after many times of use, they do not meet the requirements of thousands of hours of life in the current industry, and it is still the focus of the research to further improve the stability of the catalysts. Second, energy efficiency enhancement. We still need to further strengthen the reaction process, optimize the catalyst composition, reactor and reaction conditions, etc., so as to achieve low energy consumption and high yield in practical applications, and reduce the distance from industrial requirements. Third, lack of extensive research on the reaction mechanism. An in-depth understanding of the reaction mechanism helps us to regulate the selectivity of the reduction products, avoid the problem of too many product types. There is no need for subsequent separation of the products, which reduces energy consumption. Fourth, we need to further reduce the difference between the experimental conditions and the actual application, so that it is close to the real state, in order to reduce or avoid the inefficiency or the emergence of new problems in the actual application. Whether it is experimental research or theoretical research, we need to establish a more perfect modeling plan, comprehensively consider the possible influencing factors, and achieve the lowest impact in the process of industrial amplification. To overcome these shortcomings and challenges, we propose the following research directions and perspectives. (1) Development of high-performance catalysts. First, for the new catalysts proposed in the paper, we should actively innovate and explore on the Cu2O system. For example，for single-atom/cluster catalysts, the theoretical studies are relatively mature, but their precise preparation is still difficult, and there are great difficulties to be overcome for practical applications；for the doped/loaded system, the introduction of the second component has been proven to have a positive effect on the CO2RR, we can conduct research on more types of elements and double doping/loading systems; in addition, there are also FLPs and tandem catalysts, etc. The mature application of these new catalysts is expected to break through the limitation of catalytic activity and stability of Cu2O. (2) Generation of high-value products. Second, the reduction of CO2 to C2+ high-value products is a very attractive technological mean. Compared with C1 products such as CO and HCOOH, C2 products such as C2H4 and C2H5OH have higher energy density and added value [282]. The key to the formation of C2 products is the strength of the adsorption energy of the important intermediates on the catalyst surface. A suitable adsorption energy facilitates the C-C coupling reaction without causing desorption or hinderinfg its further reaction due to too strong or too weak adsorption energy. In addition, it is required to overcome the larger reaction potential in the C-C formation process. Based on this paper, the Cu2O photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to C1 products is relatively mature, but it is still challenging for C2 products, and we need to further develop and explore new Cu2O-based catalysts. For the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2, Cu2O is inherently better at C2 generation, and it also shows some activity towards the generation of C3 products. We need to build on this foundation to further overcome the challenges of high energy barriers and slow kinetics of the reaction. In conclusion, we seek to efficiently and directionally generate products with more added value. This has been the goal of our research for a long time. (3) Application of theoretical tools (Interdisciplinary cooperation). Thirdly, the application of ML and DFT in exploring catalysts help us to prove the expected mechanism, selectivity and efficiency, provide a detailed reaction mechanism and save our time and cost. Theoretical studies of the reaction system by ML and DFT can better predict the performance of the catalyst and identify the reactive sites. And it also helps us better understand the effects of crystal facet, doping and loading on the reaction. We should strengthen the combination of theoretical calculations and experimental studies, which is essential to understand the catalytic mechanism and improve the catalytic performance. (4) Reaction Rate Enhancement. Finally, for the electrocatalytic CO2RR, the reactor design and the optimization of the electrodes are also crucial to improve the reaction efficiency, which will effectively increase the photocurrent density, accelerate the reaction kinetics, and improve the stability of the catalyst. In recent years, gas diffusion electrodes (GDEs) have been widely used in CO2RR [283–286]. As a kind of porous membrane electrode, GDEs can enhance the mass transport of CO2 to the catalyst and overcome the limitation of CO2 solubility in aqueous electrolytes. GDEs with hydrophobic and porous characteristic substrates can realize higher current density and effectively shorten the diffusion distance of CO2, which has a good development prospect. In order to ensure the stability of the gas diffusion layer (GDL), we need to pay special attention to its porosity and hydrophobicity, which are the key parameters affecting the water and gas transport, and are the focus of our material improvement research. In addition, facing the slow kinetic reaction and high energy consumption of OER at the anode in the electrocatalytic CO2RR process, we can couple CO2RR with organic oxidation reactions (methanol oxidation [287], formaldehyde oxidation [288], etc.). Building them into membrane electrode assemblies generates chemicals with higher added value. In short, optimizing the reaction environment and composition of the catalyst is of great significance to the overall performance of the catalyst. Overall, the development of catalysts with high activity, selectivity and long-term stability is an ongoing goal. In addition to the performance enhancement research, we should also consider the catalyst from the perspective of its practical application. We should pay attention to the research of catalyst deactivation mechanism to ensure that it can be stable and effective in the long term. We hope that this article can provide a systematic guide to the treatment of CO2 with Cu2O-based catalysts, which can help in the resource utilization of CO2. coredata.dc:description: Carbon dioxide (CO2) reduction reaction (CO2RR) with renewable energy represents a promising way for effective utilization of the major anthropogenic greenhouse gas. Cuprous oxide (Cu2O)-based catalysts have attracted great attention in recent years due to abundant reserves, lower price, environmental friendliness, and higher activity of CO2RR. Moreover, Cu+ site in Cu2O plays an important role in improving the C2+ product selectivity. This paper reviews recent advances of photo- and electrocatalytic CO2RR on Cu2O-based catalysts in both experimental and computational studies. Firstly, the basic principle of photo- and electrocatalytic CO2RR on Cu2O-based catalysts is briefly reviewed. Secondly, various strategies have been adopted to improve CO2RR catalytic performance of Cu2O-based catalysts, mainly including morphology control, heterojunction engineering, metal deposition, and defective engineering. Finally, potential strategies to further promote CO2RR have also been suggested: including single atom catalyst, double atom catalyst, single cluster catalyst, and frustrated Lewis pairs, etc. We hope that the present comprehensive overview paves the way for future development of CO2RR on Cu2O-based catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Photo-/electrocatalytic approaches to CO2 conversion on Cu2O-based catalysts
